Currently, she purchases turkeys and raises them for sale. Now, she needs a loan of $1200 to buy additional turkeys and fodder in order to further increase her income.

loans.use: To buy turkeys and fodder

loans.name: Bakhtiyar

texts.en: Bakhtiyar was born in 1983. He is single and lives in Khachmaz town. He has been in the cattle breeding business for 4 years. Now he needs a loan of $950 to buy one cattle. By having more cattle, he can increase his business.

loans.use: To buy one cattle

payments.comment: Correction due to underpayment for business 23216

loans.name: Gorret

texts.en:
Gorret is 35 and single with 2 children of her own.  She also cares for 2 orphans.  She has a produce stand on the main rutted dirt road of her village Makindye.  Today she is selling tomatoes, cabbage, pumpkin, avocado, eggplant, lemons, g-nuts, dried fish and greens.  She has operated her business at this location for the past 5 years and has been a member of her lending group for the past year.

With her loan she hopes to add charcoal as one of her products.  Charcoal is inexpensive and very important for outside cooking.  It is her desire to expand her business by slowly adding new items to her inventory.

As an interesting side note, most of the people I meet are very welcoming.  In fact, when you arrive in their village the universal phrase is, “You are most welcome”.  They are also easy to laugh and smile, and they love to have their picture taken.  I always ask permission first, and they take the picture very seriously.  They often will brush their hair and tidy themselves.  When it’s time to take their picture, they will rarely smile.  Once the photo is taken they immediately go back to smiling and laughing.  Oh well, I’ll keep trying to capture their wonderful spirit!

loans.use: Gorret plans to use the loan to buy more charcoal & matooke for her retail business.

loans.name: Nushaba

texts.en: Nushaba (her husband is pictured) is a mother of two children. She was born in 1974. A.'s family lives in Khachmaz town. She and her husband buy the grain from the villages and grind wheat in a mill for sales. Now this family needs a loan of $950 to buy grain.

loans.use: To buy  grain

payments.comment: Correction due to underpayment for business 23218

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes owns the Agnes Beauty Salon in the village of Makindye on the outskirts of Kampala.  She is married with 5 children and she cares for 2 orphans.  She has owned her business for 10 years and has been a part of her lending group for 2 years.  

Her salon is in a stand-alone shanty-shack located on dirt road.  The floor dirt is covered with a rolled out piece of colorful vinyl.  She has decorated the salon with posters.  There is no electricity so she does not have a hair dryer.

With her loan she plans to buy braids, weaves and chemicals.  Agnes dreams of one day buying a plot of land and building her own home.

loans.use: Agnes plans to use the loan to buy braids,weaves and chemicals for her salon.

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence is 40 years old, married with 5 children and she cares for 4 orphans.  She is the very much in control as the owner of the Good Feeding Restaurant and Bar.  She is the woman sitting in the front of the photo and her guests are seated behind her.  

Small restaurants and bars in villages serve a special need for people to escape for a while without leaving their village.  Some food and some drink inside a dark but comforting shack provides that respite.  Often, these places make their own alcohol.  I asked how they make their alcohol and was told they use tea leaves mixed with sugar, pineapple and yeast.  Outside her restaurant, which you enter via a draped doorway, she had a large pot over a charcoal cooker.  Today in the pot were pork and beans.

Florence plans to use her loan to buy more sodas and foodstuffs for her restaurant.  She dreams of one day building her own home.

loans.use: Florence plans to use the loan to buy more sodas and foodstuffs for her restaurant.

loans.name: Harriet

texts.en:
Harriet has a retail produce stand located on the main dirt road to her village.  She is 45, widowed with 4 children and 2 dependents.  She has operated the stand for 10 years and has been a member of her lending group for the past year. 

The diet of the villagers is not varied and most of the produce stands sell the same items - some are just more stocked than others.  The diet, though not varied, is usually quite fresh and not lacking in significant vitamin and mineral needs.  A typical diet consists of matooke (steamed or cooked unripe bananas), posho (maize flour), cassava (tubers), g-nuts (ground nuts), dried fish, Irish potatoes and various fruits and vegetables.  The avocados are delicious.

Today, her stand is low on produce for she is only selling tomatoes and bananas.  She plans to use her loan to increase her produce and to buy matooke, cabbage, onions, g-nuts, dried fish, eggplant and greens.

loans.use: Harriet plans to use the loan to buy matooke,cabbage,onions,g-nuts,dried fish,eggplant and greens

loans.name: Frank

texts.en:
Frank S. is a butcher and meat seller.  At his store he receives large, pre-butchered slabs of beef and goat; no pork.  There is no refrigeration, so he must be sure to only buy what he can sell in a very short time.  Also, there is no way to avoid keeping flies and other insects from landing on the meat.  The slabs are placed on a hanging hook and he carves off the amount customers want and then weighs the amount.  I often wonder about the sanitary conditions of such places, but cooking well goes a long way to alleviating health problems.

Frank serves a very important need in his community, for without meat people could easily be lacking in sufficient protein intake.  Goat is more expensive than beef and is used a lot in stews and for festive occasions.  

With his loan, Frank plans to expand his business.  Right now, the need for his meat is high so he plans to buy larger quantities of meat to meet the demand.  Frank is 25, single with no children of his own, but he does take care of two orphans.  His dream is to one day buy a plot of land and build a home.

loans.use: Frank plans to use his loan to buy more beef and goat meat

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is 30 years old, single and raising 4 children of her own and 4 orphans.  She has a tailoring boutique, which she has operated since she was 15 years old.  She has developed a good sense of business over the years and has very defined goals and dreams.  

She plans to build a small commercial building that she can use as a workshop and rent the rest.  She buys high quality cloth from Dubai and stitches simple but elegant designs.  Today she shows me some of her work.  It is clean and classy and the material is of high quality.

Sarah has been a member of her lending group for one year.  With her loan she plans to buy more cloth, embroidery and colored thread.  She wants to increase her inventory of material to be ready for the holiday workload.

loans.use: Sarah plans to use her loan to buy more cloth and embroidery to be ready for the holiday season

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter has an established business in one of the few permanent commercial structures in his village of Makindye.  On his neatly stocked shelves he sells liquor, soft drinks, water and fruit juices.  Through a draped doorway in the back of the shop he lives with his wife, 2 children and one orphan.

He has been operating his business for 5 years and has been a member of his lending group for one year.  His business is a busy meeting place for the village as he has a concrete stoop and a nice acacia shade tree.  There are chairs and benches for people to rest and visit.  On the day I visited, there were lots of mothers watching after their children and passing the time.  Once a week, his lending group also meets in front of his store.

Peter is a very determined person.  In time, he plans to build a commercial building which he will use part of for his own retail business, and rent the rest of the space.  For now, he plans to use his loan to add to his inventory of beverages, which are currently low in stock.

loans.use: Peter plans to use his loan to add to his inventory of beverages.

loans.name: Abdallah

texts.en: Abdallah is a fourty-year-old father of two and a resident of the Lumo area in Dar Es Salaam city. He has been in business for the past ten years. He is currently running a shop selling fresh fruits and vegetables in Lumo, a business which sometimes is not friendly, mainly during the dry season. He is in need of USD 400 to help him boost his business.

loans.use: EXPAND BUSINESS

loans.name: Ahmed

texts.en: Ahmed is a civil technician with over ten years of experience and rents out equipment for construction. He tendered for the construction of most of the residential houses in the Lumo area. He is in need of USD 325 to help him acquire more equipment.

loans.use: BUY MORE EQUIPMENT

loans.name: Mariama

texts.fr: Le GIE Sante Yalla est une structure qui est déjà  fonctionnelle et fait de l aviculture entre autre activités .Elle a subit une formation en ce sens. Elle déroule un projet avicole mais la demande excède  de loin son offre. C’est dans ce contexte que nous sollicitons un prêt au près de vous pour pouvoir renforcer notre activité et améliorer notre rendement afin de faire face qu exigence du marche .La gestion est commune et l’entretien se fait a tour de rôle. Les bénéfices sont réinvestit jusqu’a l’obtention d’un fonds propre nous permettant de travailler sans prêt.  Note: there are twenty-one members in this group and the photograph is featuring those that were available for the photograph when the Loan Officer visited.

loans.use: Aviculture

loans.name: Arona

texts.fr:
Le niveau actuel de couverture des besoins en éducation pour la catégorie classée  dans la petite enfance est très faible dans la commune d’arrondissement de thiaroye sur mer. L’Etat devant l’immensité de la tâche ne semble pas être en mesure de fournir partout où le besoin se fait sentir un cadre adéquat pour l’épanouissement de cette catégorie. Partant de ce fait, le secteur a besoin d’initiatives venant des collectivités de base qui doivent être conscientes de la nécessité de participer à leur prise en charge. C’est pourquoi  initiative de thiaroye sur mer pour la solidarité et le développement (ITSD)_qui ambitionne de participer au relèvement de l’offre d’éducation préscolaire et de participer à l’amélioration de la qualité de l’éducation préscolaire a ouvert une école communautaire qui est subventionnée par les membres de la dite association. C’est donc dans un souci d’atteinte de ses objectifs que venons solliciter ce prêt au près de vous. Ce prêt nous permettra de renforcer les activités dans ce domaine.les eleves font une participation financiere mensuelle qui nous permettra entre autre activité de remboursé ce prêt.

Note: there are eleven members in this group and the photograph features the Group Leader.

loans.use: Remforcement en besoins de fonctionnement d'une école maternelle

loans.name: Khady

texts.fr:
La commune d’arrondissement de Thiaroye sur mer est une commune où sévit encore la pauvreté. Mais la population  très travailleuse lutte chaque jour pour sortir de cette situation. C’est ce contexte de lutte contre la pauvreté que les membres du gie diappo liggueye qui ont pour objectif le progrès socio économique de ses membre en particulier s’est inscrit dans  e projet et sollicite vote appui. Les activités tournent globalement autour du commerce .les cinq bénéficiaires sont déjà actives et compte renforcer leurs activités voir les diversifier.. ce prêt sera divisé entre les cinq bénéficiaire . Nous aurons le groupe de Celles qui ferons de la transformation de produits locaux en jus de fruit. Celles qui feront seront dans le commerce de légumes et des produits halieutiques et produit divers .et celles qui seront dans la teinture et la ventes des tissus teints.

Note: there are five members in this group and only three were available to be photographed at the time the Loan Officer visited.

loans.use: 1ere activité : vente de jus de fruit et de crème glacées ,2eme activité : teinture et vente de tissu ,3eme activité : vente de légumes , produit halieutique et produit divers

loans.name: Aofiafilifaieseaupuo

texts.en: Aofiafilifaieseaupuosamoais is single, 30 years old and runs a very successful business selling pancakes to the people of her village and to students in local schools. She would like to increase her income, and has applied for a loan of $300 to buy ingredients -- such as flour, sugar, fat and yeast -- that she needs to make and sell more pancakes. She is very happy with the way her business is growing, and hopes that this loan will help it continue to expand and make possible more growth and more loans in the future .

loans.use: To buy ingredients and supplies for her pancakes business

loans.name: Uiga Iosefa

texts.en: Uiga is 24 years old and married with one daughter. She works very hard raising vegetables on her small farm because this is her family's sole means of support. Fortunately, she earns a good income selling her crops in the market and all around her village. Her dream is to buy the tools and chemicals she needs to increase her output and thereby improve her family's life. She has come to us for a loan for $300 to buy the items she needs to make these increased yields a reality

loans.use: To buy tools and supplies for her vegetable garden

loans.name: Fipe

texts.en: Fipe is married with two children and shares a house with her extended family. Her husband was the only person in their home who was employed until Fipe decided to help support her family by opening her own small business selling cold desserts such as shaved ice and ice cakes. She opened her business with the help of a $300 loan, which she paid back by selling her products daily in her village and at the local school. Now she has applied for a new loan of $300 to buy a big freezer, to use along with the small one she has had since opening her business.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her business selling cold desserts

loans.name: Sita

texts.en: Sita is 21 years old, married and has one daughter. She stays home to look after her elderly parents, but recently began to help her husband meet the needs of their family by opening up a small business selling shoes. This business is off to a good start, and she has come to us for a loan of $300 to buy additional inventory to sell from tables she has set up on the side of her house. With this loan, she believes that she can expand her business and fulfill her dream of helping her family live a better life.

loans.use: To resupply her shop

loans.name: Romafou

texts.en: Romafou is married, has two children and lives with her parents, sisters and brothers in one house. She runs a fast-food stall which is popular with the people of her village, and also sells her goods at school, work places and around town. She has applied for a loan of $120 to buy the ingredients and supplies she needs to run her business, and hopes that the loan will help her generate the income she need to take better care of her family, especially her children.

loans.use: To buy ingredients and supplies for her fast food stall

loans.name: Tailoto

texts.en: Tailoto is 23 years old and married with one daughter. She runs a profitable business selling cold desserts such as shaved ice and ice cakes to the people of her village and to students at the local school. She has come to us for a loan of $300 to buy more ingredients , such as ice blocks, cordials, sugar and plastic bags. With this loan, she will be able to expand her business and provide a better income for her family.

loans.use: To buy ingredients and supplies for her business selling cold desserts

loans.name: Solinuu

texts.en: Solinuu is 31 years old, married and has three children. She is very talented at making and producing handicrafts, especially Samoan designs for items such as earrings, rings, necklaces and hats. She has been in this business for five years, but faces a serious problem: to expand her business, and her income, she needs to buy expensive tools, such as drill, that she simply cannot afford. She has applied for a loan of $300 to buy these tools, which will allow her to provide a better life for herself and her family.

loans.use: To buy tools for her handicrafts business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Invest in new holiday season products

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en: Josephine is 61 years old and has eight children. Her husband died 10 years ago, and since that time she has raised and provided for her family on her own. She has a small shop that is open seven days a week and sells items needed by the people of her village. She has applied for a loan of $300 to buy inventory to sell. She believes that the loan will help her earn more income, and may also allow her to employee three of her children as helpers.

loans.use: To restock her shop

loans.name: Alesi

texts.en: Alesi is 42 years old and married with four children. She runs a small business selling items needed by the people of her village from several tables she has set up alongside her house. In the past, she used a $300 loan to purchase inventory, and was very pleased at the return she earned and the ability it gave her to meet the needs of her family and educate her children.  Now she has come to us for a second loan, which she will use to build a small enclosure where she can sell her goods and in which she can also store them while she is away.

loans.use: To restock her shop

loans.name: Koreti

texts.en: Koreti is 42 years old and married with three children. She is so good at barbecuing foods that she went into business selling what she cooks. She makes a good income and helps support her family by selling food along the road, particularly on weekends, to people who are passing into and out of her village. She has come to us for a loan of $300 to buy meat to barbecue, and ingredients and seasonings such as soy and tomato sauce, onions and salt.

loans.use: To buy meat and other ingredients for her barbecue

loans.name: Sipili

texts.en: Sipili U. is 31 years old and married with four children. She is very good at sewing different types of clothes -- so good, in fact, that she believes her skills are a gift from God. Most of her clients come to her home with items they want sewed or repaired, but if things are slow she makes new garments and sells them for a good price at local flea markets. Sipili loves what she does for a living, and is very grateful for the monetary assistance she has received in the past. She has applied for a loan of $300 to buy more of the tools she needs to practice her trade, such as material, thread and needles.

loans.use: To buy tools for her sewing business

loans.name: Doreen

texts.en: Doreen is a 42-year-old lady with five children. She is very hard-working and puts a lot of effort in running her sales business. With the income from her flea market stand, Doreen supports her family. She is asking for a loan of US$300 to buy various items she sells in her flea market stand. The items include vegetables, Samoan cocoa, plantation crops such as taro and bananas, and handicrafts. She hopes to make around 180 Tala (US$72) of net profit a day six days per week.

loans.use: Purchase of inventory and supplies for a flea market stall

loans.name: Faaatualoa

texts.en: Faaatualoa is a sixty-three year old lady with three children; her husband died five years ago. Despite her respectable age, she still runs her baking business. She sells baked goods at a local school, as well as in a shop in the village, and is very happy about the success of her business so far. Faaatualoa is asking for a loan of US$475 to buy ingredients needed for her bakery such as flour, sugar, yeast and a new oven burner.

loans.use: Purchase of ingredients and supplies for a bakery

loans.name: Tina

texts.en: Tina has been divorced from her husband for three years now, and has been responsible for earning her family's income ever since. Together with her two sons, she works on the family's plantation in order to make a living. Tina has applied for a loan of US$300, which she plans to use to buy chemicals and tools necessary for the plantation. She hopes to sell the produce grown on the plantation at a local market, and to make 240 Tala (US$96) in weekly profit.

loans.use: Purchase of chemicals and tools for a plantation

loans.name: Suifua

texts.en: Suifua is a fifty-nine year old lady, married, with six children. She has been running her shop for about five years, and the business has been successful so far. However, Suifua needs financial help for further business expansion. She has joined the SPBD program and hopes to obtain her first loan of US$300, which will be used to re-stock the shop. Suifua is very excited to receive outside help, and thinks she is going to be able to stay in business. Her shop is open seven days a week, and, with the help of the loan, Suifua hopes to make a net profit of 180 Tala (US$72) a day.

loans.use: Purchase of goods to replenish the stock of a shop

loans.name: Lesina

texts.en: Lesina is 41 years old, married, and has seven children. She works on the family-owned plantation, and has applied for this loan in order to be able to afford chemicals and tools. She will sell the produce grown on the plantation at a local flea market about three days per week. Lesina hopes to make a profit of 240 Tala (US$96) a day, which will greatly help her support her family. Lesina is very thankful for the financial support provided by the loan program.

loans.use: Purchase of chemicals and tools for a plantation

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for South Pacific Business Development (SPBD) - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Tala

texts.en: Tala is a 21-year ol lady, married, and has a son. She works very hard on her vegetable garden, which is her only source of income. Tala sells vegetables at a local market three days per week, as well as in the village early in the mornings. She has applied for a loan of US$300, which will be used to buy weed-killing chemicals and tools such as knives and a new watering hose. Tala hopes to expand her garden with another loan later on, once she has repaid the current one.

loans.use: Purchase of chemicals and tools for a vegetable garden

loans.name: Sesilia

texts.en: Sesilia  is 22 years old, married, with two children. She works very hard in her vegetable garden, since she is the only bread-winner for the family. Sesilia sells vegetables at a market three days per week and makes a net profit of 160 Tala (US$64) a day. She has applied for a loan of US$300 to buy chemicals and tools needed for the business. Sesilia plans to borrow more in the future to further expand her plantation business.

loans.use: Purchase of chemicals and tools for a vegetable garden

loans.name: Martha Lorena

texts.es:
Mrs. Martha B. is originally from Bluefields. Martha is 50 years old and her life long mate, Mr. Benacio Quintero, is 51 years old. The two of them have five children, three of which still live at home. Mrs. Balladeres owns a grocery store, which she has had for more than 15 years. Her clients range from children to men and women of all ages and they appreciate that she sells a wide variety of products (basic necessities, canned goods, school supplies, and personal hygiene).Mrs. B. wants to purchase 2 glass display cases so that she can better exhibit her pastries, sweet breads, and cosmetics. This will allow her to increase the variety of the products she offers. Each window costs $139.00.

Translated from Spanish by Casey Unrein, Kiva volunteer.

La Sra. Martha B. es originaria de la ciudad de Bluefields, tiene 50 años de edad, su pareja de vida es el Sr. Benacio Quintero de 51 años,ambos tiene 5 hijos, 3 viven con la pareja. La Sra. B. es la propietaria de una abarroteria , teniendo más de 15 años de experiencia, siendo sus clientes niños, hombre y mujeres de todas las edades prefiriendola por ofrecer variedades de productos (productos basicos, productos enlatados, productos escolares, productos de cuido personal). La Sra. B. quiere comprar 2 vitrinas de vidrio para poder exhibir productos de reposteria o de pan dulce y de cosmesticos de esta manera poder aumentar la variedad de productos que oferta, cada vitrina cuesta $139.00 dolares.

loans.use: Purchase of two glass display cases.

payments.comment: La cuota de la microempresaria es de US$23.17
La cuota real de pago es de $ 23.17 dólares
La cuota real de pago es de $23.17 dólares
la cuota real de pago es de $ 23.17 dólares.
La cuota real es de $ 23.17 dólares.
La cuota real de pago es de $ 23.17 dólares

loans.name: Juan Ramon

texts.es:
Juan Ramon M. C. is 41 years old and lives with his wife and two children  in Bluefields.  His two children go to primary school.  Mr. M. has worked for 10 years transporting goods for businesses in Bluefields.  To do so Mr. M. uses a wooden cart pulled by horse.  Mr. M. has permanent contracts with various businesses.  He is well known by the shopkeepers and he has a fixed clientele.  Still, his cart is deteriorating and two months ago his horse died.  Without his horse it is much more difficult to carry goods in short periods of time.  Due to all of this Mr. M. needs to buy a horse and repair his cart.  The horse will cost $160, the six 2x4x12 boards will cost $3 each, and the six 1x12x12 boards with cost $5 each.

Translated from Spanish by Casey Unrein, Kiva volunteer.


Juan Ramon M. C. tiene 41 años, vive en Bluefields es casado tiene 2 hijos los cuales se encuentran estudiando en nivel primaria. El señor M. desde hace 10 años sde dedica a transportar mercaderia para algunos negocios de esta ciudad de Bluefields y para tal actividad utiliza una carreta de madera la que es jalada por un caballo. Don Juan Ramon es contratado por varios negocios de manera permanente lo que le permite tener una clientela fija, ya que este es conocido por muchos comerciantes. Sin embargo ya su carreta esta bastante deteriorada y desde hace dos meses se le murio su caballo por lo que el tiene que jalar dicha carreta lo que se le hace bastante dificil trasladar en menos tiempo las mercaderias. Por lo anterior el señor M. necesita comprar un caballo y reparar su carreta, el caballo  esta valorado en US$ 160 dolares, las 6 piezas de madera de 2x4x12 valoradas en US$ 3 dolares cada una y 6 piezas de madera de 1x12x12 valoradas en US$ 5 dolares cada una.

loans.use: Purchase of a horse and materials to repair cart (six 2x4x12 boards and six 1x4x12 boards).

payments.comment: Pago antes de la fecha que le correspondia, le tocaba hasta el dia 10-Diciembre-2007. El microempresario manifesto que ya habia recogido su cuota y preferia pagarla.
Abono US$ 12.45. Este microempresario a tenido problemas para realizar los repagos y acordamos que estara abonando a su credito.

loans.name: Faalagilagi

texts.en: Faalagilagi is 36 years old, married, and a mother of 3. Her husband works for one of the local factories, and the family owns a plantation and a vegetable garden as additional sources of income. However, raising three children has been difficult, because her husband's income is not sufficient even to pay the bills and the children's school fees. Therefore, Faalagilagi has decided to invest more time and money in the plantation and the vegetable garden, because she believes that the family can thus earn more. Faalagilagi first heard about SPBD through the village women, and was very delighted to join, so that she could get an opportunity to develop her business. She has applied for her first loan of US$300, and is very confident that her business will successfully expand.

loans.use: Purchase of fertilizers, chemicals, and other supplies for a vegetable garden

loans.name: Suitulaga

texts.en: Suitulaga comes from a family of twelve children. She got married 7 years ago and has 4 children. Suitulaga's husband works in a supermarket. He is very hard-working, always working in the plantation also after work and during the weekends. The couple has decided to improve their plantation. Suitulaga, therefore, joined SPBD, and is very happy about her decision, since she can now borrow money to buy the equipment she needs for her plantation. Suitulaga is asking for a loan of US$300, and is very thankful for such a great opportunity to develop her business.

loans.use: Purchase of equipment for a plantation

loans.name: Faasalia Umusa

texts.en: Faasalia is 53 years old, married, and a mother of 7 children. The family has been living on their plantation for a long time, and it is their only source of income. Faasalia and her husband sell taro in a market three days a week, and the money they get is enough to pay for their children's school fees and to buy their daily groceries. Faasalia hopes to keep her business growing, and is therefore asking for a loan of US$1,125, which will be her 4th loan with SPBD. Faasalia is very thankful for this great opportunity.

loans.use: Purchase of supplies and equipment for a plantation

loans.name: Leaia

texts.en: Leaia is 59 years old, married, with 8 children and 15 grand-children. Having a large family has always been financially difficult, but, despite the hard times, Leaia has managed to find solutions. She is now running her beach fales business on the eastern side of the island of Upolu, and is asking for a loan of US$1,200. This is her 4th loan with SPBD, and she will use it to renovate the fales.

loans.use: Renovation of beach fales (Samoan lodging huts for tourists)

loans.name: Faapaia

texts.en: Faapaia is 27 years old and single. She lives with her father and three brothers. She used to work as a school teacher, but, when her mother passed away 6 months ago, Faapaia decided to stay home to look after her sick father. She also decided to earn money on her own that would let her be financially independent of her brothers. Faapaia is therefore asking for a loan of US$475 to improve her small restaurant business. This is Faapaia's second loan with SPBD, and she is very delighted that her business is going well.

loans.use: Purchase of supplies and materials for a pancake business

loans.name: Marcial

texts.es:
My wife needs more space in our home. I would like to expand the kitchen. I have tried to make my family comfortable in our home. I started with the construction of the house and little by little I have achieved a larger space. I ask for $800.00 in order to expand the kitchen in my home.

Translated from Spanish by Casey Unrein, Kiva volunteer.

“Mi esposa necesita un poco más de espacio en nuestra casa así es que me gustaría ampliar la cocina un poco, he tratado de que mi familia este cómoda, empecé con la construcción de mi casa y poco a poco he logrado tener más espacio. Solicito $ 800.00 dlls para ampliar la cocina de mi casa

loans.use: Expansion of the kitchen

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Fundación para la Vivienda Progresiva (FVP), a partner of CHF International - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Maura

texts.es: ESTE CASO ESTA DUPLICADO FAVOR DE ELIMINAR

loans.use: CASO DUPLICADO

loans.name: Ani

texts.en: Ani is 30 years old and married. She sells candied fruit and is in business with her husband. They earn about $13 per day. Ani would like a loan of $75 (IDR 500,000) to buy more goods and increase the income for her children's education. She's a member of MBK and is willing to repay this loan within 12 months.

loans.use: To buy more goods

loans.name: Ema

texts.en: Ema J. is 29 years old and married. She has a small shop that sells snacks and a few household goods. She usually earns $10 per day with a small profit. Her husband is an employee and earns about $33 per week. Ema would like a loan of $150 (IDR 1,200,000)  to buy more goods for her shop. She's a member of MBK and is willing to repay this loan within 12 months.

loans.use: To buy more goods and complete her shop

loans.name: Dan

texts.en:
Dan is a well educated 29 year old. He has a wife and one child. And, he takes care of 6 orphans. He went to the university and received his teacher’s degree but wanted to work for himself. So, he went back and received a degree in computer science. Combining both degrees, Dan has returned to his home village, and started his new business which is called Global Information Center. 

His business is an internet café, but it is also much more for the people in his village of Mperewe. It is an unusual sight to see computers outside the major cities of Uganda. But Dan is determined to provide them with this service. A year ago he had two computers, now he has eight. And, he uses his business to teach students computer science. As Dan emphasized  “In the global world, the children of Mperewe need to know how to use computers. With it they will gain much information and information will empower them”.

With his loan, Dan plans to buy furniture for his business. He owns a plot of land and his dream is to build a permanent computer training center on the site.

loans.use: Dan plans to buy furniture for his internet cafe.

loans.name: Ai

texts.en: Ai K. is 38 years old and married. She sells cooked foods such as noodles, fried snacks, etc., and usually earns $10 per day. Her husband Sugiarto is working at the shop and earns about $10 per week.  Ai is a member of MBK and would like a loan of $75 (IDR 500,000) to buy more goods for the store and pay for her children's education. She is willing to repay this loan within 12 months.

loans.use: To buy more goods

loans.name: Firangiz

texts.en: Firangiz (her husband is pictured) has a fruit orchard which she has been tending for 5 years. This 48-year-old woman has three children and lives in Khachmaz town. Now Firangiz's family needs a loan of $600 to buy fertilizer and weed control products for their orchard.

loans.use: Firangiz would like to buy weed control and fertilizer.

payments.comment: Correction due to underpayment for business 23262

loans.name: Aminah

texts.en: Aminah is 35 years old and married. She sells fruit and snacks to supplement her family's income, usually earning $22 per day. Her husband has no fixed income at the moment. Aminah is a member of MBK and asks for a loan of $125 (IDR 1,000,000) to expand her shop. Part of the loan will be used to improve her husband's business. She willing to repay this loan within 12 months.

loans.use: To expand her shop

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty is the very cordial and embracing owner of the Mpererwe High School, in the village of the same name. She is married with two children. She has operated her school for three years and currently has 120 children enrolled. It is a private school offering classes in Secondary and Advanced studies. Secondary is 4 years from ages 14 to 18 and advanced is 2 years from 18 to 20. Students pay about $40.00 per term plus the cost of uniforms and books. There are three terms in a year. The school gets no outside funding. Financially it is not easy to run a private school, but the public schools lack a great deal and have only recently offered Secondary and Advanced studies. So the need for private schools is great.

Betty plans to use her loan to install power to her school so that she can buy a computer for her students to use. Her dream is to one day buy a plot of land and build her own school. For now, she rents the space of a school which had closed down. With her energy and enthusiasm for her students,  she hopes to attain her dream. She is a wonderful, strong woman.

loans.use: Betty plans to use her loan to install power to her school so that she can install a computer for her students

loans.name: Emi

texts.en: Emi is 60 years old and married. She lives with her son's family, which includes three grandchildren. She has a small shop stocked with rice, snacks, and vegetables, where she earns about $3 per day. Emi would like a loan of $75 (IDR 500,000) to expand her shop. She is a member of MBK and can repay this loan within 12 months.

loans.use: To expand her shop

loans.name: Fredah

texts.en:
Fredah B. and her husband own the St. James Memorial Medical Center and Nursing Home. Her husband is the doctor at the clinic and they live on the premises with their 3 children and two orphans. They have been offering medical services at the clinic for 6 years. Malaria patients are  the largest part of their care followed by counseling to HIV/AID’s patients. The clinic provides 24 services which also include general practice, overnight nursing care and lab work.

With their loan they plan to buy a hemo-meter to do in-house blood work. This will help them to determine patients with diabetes and other blood related health concerns. In villages, these private centers are critical for without them there would be no health care. Since it is private pay, this is truly a labor of love for the doctor and his wife. She is also involved in many community leadership positions.

loans.use: Fredah and her husband plan to use their loan to buy a hemo-meter to do in house blood work at their clinic.

loans.name: Abdalah

texts.en:
ABDALAH, age 42, is the father of 3 boys. He and his wife have started businesses within the past two years to support their family. In February 2006, Abdalah opened a shop where he sells vegetables, sodas, ice pops, and general-needs items. His shop has around 45 customers each day, and from them, he makes a profit of around $9. In the past, Abdalah has taken out two successful loans and hopes to take out a third loan, which will also be used to build up his shop’s inventory.

In January of this year, Abdalah’s wife was able to open her own breakfast café, which brings a profit of about $2.50 a day. Because of starting these businesses, Abdalah and his wife say that they no longer have problems paying general expenses such as school fees and hospital bills.

Abdalah belongs to the group Songambele (Swahili for “going forward”), which consists of 21 other members who keep each other accountable and insure one another in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To increase inventory

loans.name: Aisha

texts.en:
Aisha N. is 60 years old and widowed. She had 10 children but 6 have passed away. She takes care of 8 of her grandchildren.
Aisha has a produce stand where she sells matooke ( a kind of plantain, irish potatoes, tomatoes, onions, pumpkins, etc. She has had the stand for 10 years and has been in her lending group for 8 months. This is her second loan and with it she plans to buy more produce for her stand. Her dream is to be able to educate her grandchildren and to build a house for them. Aisha is a very friendly and well liked person with a wonderful sense of humor.

loans.use: Aisha plans to use her loan to buy more matooke, tomatoes, Irish potatoes, onions, etc. for her produce stand.

loans.name: Godlisen

texts.en:
GODLISEN is 38 years old and the father of twin 5-year-old boys. Having started a shop two years ago, he is able to support his wife and children. His shop sells vegetables, juice, lotions, candy, bread, fish, notebooks, rice, and other general items. Every day, his shop receives around 20 customers and takes in a profit of about $9. In the past, Godlisen has taken out two successful loans and now he hopes to take out another loan to once again expand his inventory. The first two loans were used to purchase tomatoes in Iringa, a town about 9 hours away by bus. Godlisen hopes to use this new loan to purchase Irish potatoes in Iringa.

Godlisen belongs to the group Songambele (Swahili for “going forward”), which consists of 21 other members who keep each other accountable and insure one another in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To increase inventory

payments.comment: Godlisen was able to pay the remainder of his loan before the end of the loan term!

loans.name: Nuranda

texts.en:
I. Nuranda is 43 years old, married and the mother of five children. She is a refugee from the Azerbaijan- Armenian conflict territory Lachin region, situated in the western part of the Azerbaijan Republic in the Caucasus region. Right now she lives in Sumqayit city. She is a low-income person who is very vulnerable to shifts in the local economy.

She buys lambs and raises them in half a year. She wants to expand her business.

Nurende would like to receive a $300 loan in order to acquire three small sheep, raise them and feed them. She will repay the loan within 12 months. She hopes eventually to expand her business. She hopes that this will further improve the living conditions of her family.

loans.use: To acquire three small sheep, raise them and feed them

loans.name: Annet

texts.en:
For the past six years Annet N. has owned the Annet Unisex Hair Salon. She is married with 3 children and she cares for 5 dependents. She is new to her lending group and this is her first loan. With her loan she plans to buy braids, weaves and chemicals for her salon. A large majority of women use braids and weaves in widely varying styles. Although her clients have little money, they still find it important to tend to their hygiene and appearance.  
Annet dreams of one day buying a plot of land and building a home. This is a dream of a lot of people in the villages of Uganda. They do not want to leave their village, but they hope one day not to have to rent. Often a plot is small and a house is one or two rooms made of adobe brick.

loans.use: Annet plans to use her loan to buy more braids, weaves and chemicals for her salon.

loans.name: Nurwiti

texts.en: Nurwiti is 29 years old and married. She sells sandals on credit. She travels to other villages besides her own village to find customers.  Her earnings from this business total around $20 per week. She is a new member of MBK and would like a loan of $75 (IDR 500,000) to buy more sandals and expand her business. She is willing to repay this loan within 12 months.

loans.use: To expand her sandal business

loans.name: Srey Ny

texts.en:
Mrs. N. Srey Ny married in 1987 and has one daughter. Besides weaving the silk herself, she is also in the business of buying and reselling silk products, which she started in 2004. Her daughter weaves silk at home as well. Her husband grows rice and plants vegetables in the village. He also weaves silk when he is free from his farming duties.

She has borrowed money from MAXIMA three times. Now, she is asking for a loan of $550. She will use this loan to purchase finished silk products for her stock and resell them in the market.

loans.use: To purchase finished silk products for her stock and resell.

loans.name: Prossy

texts.en:
Prossy Nikiggude is married with 3 children. For the past seven years she has been selling used clothing, usually t-shirts, skirts and trousers. She will go to the large market in Kampala and buy at a discount and then bring the items back to her village of Mpererwe on the outskirts of Kampala and resell the items outside her home. Often people sell items outside their homes. There is no additional rent and the paths of the villages constantly have foot traffic. And, people in the village support the businesses within their community.

With her loan she plans to buy a bale of used clothes. A bale is usually a weight measure and can contain up to 1,000 used t-shirts. By buying in larger quantities Prossy can get a larger discount and will not have to make as many trips to Kampala. She is new to her lending group and this is her first loan.

loans.use: Prossy plans to use her loan to buy used clothing in larger quantities, bales, to get a better discount.

loans.name: Sofia

texts.en:
SOFIA, age 28, single-handedly supports her 7-year-old son and 8-year-old niece through her business, the “T. Shop.” Her shop sells fresh vegetables, fish, fruit, sugar, flour, and other general items. Having started her business in January of this year, she collects about $2.50 in profit each day. Her first loan, which was paid back successfully, helped to initially open the shop. Since then, she has taken out another loan, which was used to help her get back on her feet after her shop was robbed in April. As a result of the robbery, she had to repurchase a scale and restock her inventory. She now has had to also invest in hiring a community watchman to guard her shop at night. The loan she is now requesting will allow her to increase her inventory.

Sofia belongs to the group Songambele (Swahili for “going forward”), which consists of 21 other members who keep each other accountable and insure one another in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To increase inventory

payments.comment: Sophia was able to successfully repay her loan before the end of the loan term!

loans.name: Agabadji

texts.en: Agabadji is the mother of five children and a widow. She lives in Khachmaz region, Hadjilar village. This 49-year-old woman has 5 years of experience with cattle breeding. Now she needs a loan of $825 to buy one cow so she can grow her business.

loans.use: Agabadji would like to buy one cow to breed.

payments.comment: Correction due to underpayment for business 23276

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samue K.  is a teacher at Mpererwe High School. But he also saw a need for the students to be able to buy used books. So he opened a social center where he sells school books. He has operated it successfully for the past one and half years.
 
Samuel is new to his lending group and plans to use his first loan to buy a printer and more used books for his students to purchase.  Samuel is 23, single, has one child and cares for 2 orphans. He dreams of one day opening his own school for secondary and advanced education. This is a very important need for only recently has the government of Uganda started paying for education past primary school  or 14 years of age.

loans.use: Samuel plans to use his loan to buy a printer and more used books for his students to buy.

loans.name: Biyang Ayu

texts.id:
Gusti Ayu Biang S. is a widow whose husband died long ago. In her not too young age, Biang S. has to rely on her pig farm to earn a living. Previously, Biang S. raised piglets sold to butchers or restaurants. Since joining DINARI foundation, Biang S. started to develop her farm bu purchasing a breeding pig. Due to her old age, her Biyang Ayu's two daughters that live next door are helping her too. They feed the pgs twice a day, once in the morning and once in the afternoon. Every 6 months a breeder can give birth to 8 piglets. Cost for feed and medication is about $80, and she can earn about $220, so she can earn $150 per 6 months. The profit from the farm is used to pay for Biyang Ayu and her daughters' daily living expenses.

Translated from Indonesian by Kresna Hartandi, Kiva Volunteer

Gusti Ayu Biang S. adalah seorang janda, karena suaminya sudah lama meninggal. Di usianya yang sudah tidak muda lagi, untuk mencukupi keperluan hidupnya Biang S. hanya mengandalkan usaha ternak babi. Sebelumnya Biang S. memelihara bibit babi dan dijual untuk babi guling. Semejak bergabung dan mendapat bantuan dana dari Yayasan DINARI, Biang S. mulai mengembangkan dengan memembeli satu ekor induk. Karena kondisi Biang S. sudah cukup lanjut maka pemeliharaan dibantu keduan anak perempuannya yang tinggal disebelah rumahnya. Pemberian pakan dilakukan dalam sehari hanya 2 kali yaitu pagi dan sore hari. Dalam 6 bulan Induk babi melahirkan 8 ekor bibit babi. Pengeluaran pemeliharaan untuk pakan dan pengobatan menghabiskan dana Rp. 700.000,-. Total keseluruhan penjualan 8 ekor secara sistem gulingan Rp. 2.000.000,- . Total keuntungan bersih selama 6 bulan mencapai Rp.1.300.000,-. Dengan keuntungan dari usahanya dipakai untuk mencukupi keperluan sehari-hari dan memberikan upah kepada kedua anaknya perempuannya yang sudah membantu memelihara babinya untuk dapat dipakai mencukupi kebutuhan sehari-harinya.

loans.use: Purchase Breeding Pig

payments.comment: Finally she can repaid the rest of the loan. The business really help her economic life and can help her family to run this life. The loan that she had help her to improved her business. Now after finished repaid the loan, she has a plan to get another loan. She will use it to improving her business. She hope she will get the next loan soon.

loans.name: Theary

texts.en:
Mrs. C. Theary was married in 2005, and has one daughter. She started her business of selling grocery items at PREK Anh-chanh Market in 2005. Her husband has a business of pumping water into a tank and selling it from one village to another.

She has borrowed money from MAXIMA twice previously. She is now requesting a loan in the amount of $500. She will use this money to purchase more grocery items for her stock.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items for her stock

loans.name: Amsah

texts.en: Amsah is 42 years old and married. She sells vegetables to people in her village, earning $15 a day. Previously, she sold prepared food, but that business has been declined, so she would like to concentrate on fresh vegetable sales. Her husband is a laborer who earns $7 per week. She would like a loan of $75 (IDR 500,000) to accomplish her goal and is willing to repay this loan within 12 months.

loans.use: To expand sales in her store

loans.name: Khadija

texts.en:
KHADIJA, 31 years old and an elementary school teacher by profession, is an experienced businesswoman in raising chickens. From a previous loan, she raised and sold two different groups of 250 chickens. Having repaid this loan successfully, she aspires to get another loan in order to continue with and expand her business. With a new loan, she plans to purchase 750 chicks (250 broilers and 500 layers), which cost about 1 dollar each. She plans to also build another chicken coop.

Even while dealing with health concerns resulting from diabetes and a stroke that occurred less than two years ago, Khadija continues to strive to improve her business. Living with her husband, 1-year-old son, and 10-year-old stepson, she has many dreams of improving her family’s quality of life. From the profits of her business, they are currently building an addition onto the back of their home.

Khadija belongs to the group Dhahabu (Swahili for “gold”), which consists of 36 other members who keep each other accountable and insure one another in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy chicks and build additional chicken coop

payments.comment: Khadija was able to make her last payment before the end of her loan term.

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine N. is a hardworking 32year old single woman with 6 children. She also cares for 4 orphans. She has a retail store with a bar. And, she is also raising 30 pigs. The pigs will mature in 8 months at which time she will sell them.  
In her retail store Christine sells sugar, maize flour, salt, rice and g-nuts. In her bar she sells a matooke wine. Matooke wine is made from unripe bananas which are buried in the ground and covered with banana leaves for three days to soften them. Then they are roasted slightly and again buried for three days after which they are stomped in a dug out log and placed in an earthen jug to ferment for 14 days.
Christine  has been in business for 10 years and a member of her lending group for 7 years. With her loan she plans to buy maize and matooke feed for her pigs. One day she hopes to buy a pick-up truck so that she can transport her pigs to market.

loans.use: Christine plans to use her loan to buy maize and matooke feed for her pigs.

loans.name: Nawi

texts.en: Nawi is a 33 years old and married. She sells clothes and fabric on credit. She travels door to door to visit customers and collects the payment at the end of each month. She can earn $10 per week. Her husband has no fixed income. Nawi is a member of MBK and would like a loan of $125 (IDR 1,000,000) to expand her business and earn more income for her children's education. She is willing to repay this loan within 12 months.

loans.use: To buy more clothes and fabric to expand her business

loans.name: So-Khoeurn

texts.en:
Mrs. Y. So-yoeurn is divorced with 5 children. She started raising pigs in 1996, and she now has 48 baby pigs, including one mother pig. All of her children are living under her care. The eldest daughter assists her in raising the pigs at home, and the other children are studying.

She has borrowed money from MAXIMA twice. She is now requesting a loan in the amount of $600. She will use this money to purchase 20 more baby pigs to raise in the pig shed next to her house.

loans.use: To purchase 20 baby pigs

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Ikah

texts.en: Ikah is 45 years old and married. She has a small shop which sells snacks, and a few household goods. She usually earns $10 per day with a small profit. Her husband has no fixed income. Ikah would like a loan of $125 (IDR 1,000,000) to buy more goods and complete her shop. She's a member of MBK and is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To buy more goods and expand her shop

loans.name: Mastla

texts.en:
Mastla N. owns the Mercy Unisex Hair Salon in downtown Kampala. The streets in this area are very busy with vendors pushing carts, bicyclists delivering goods and the hustle and bustle of commerce and a constant flow of people. She works on her clients hair just on the second floor where there is a respite from the traffic.

Mastla is 26, married, with four children. She has owned her business for 7 years and has been a member of her lending group for 6 years. With her loan she plans to buy more braids, weaves and chemicals. Braids and weaves are very important in the lives of Ugandan women. It is one of the few things they can treat themselves to. The weaves and braids are tightly woven into their own hair in a variety of styles.

In time, Mastla would like to be able to start an additional business in which she wholesales braids, weaves and chemicals to other salons.

loans.use: Mastla plans to use her loan to buy more braids, weaves and chemicals for her beauty salon.

loans.name: Enih

texts.en: Enih is 32 years old and is married. Her husband has no fixed income. She cooks and sells food such as noodles, fried snacks, meat ball, chicken soup, and other items, and usually earns $5 per day. Enih is a member of MBK and would like a loan of $75 (IDR 500,000) loan to buy more goods and to pay for her children's education. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To buy more food ingredients for her business

loans.name: Ni Komang

texts.id:
Ni Komang S. has been farming cornish hens for a while. In the beginning she only has several chickens in the farm. Those chickens were allowed to roam around and seek their own food. Feeding is only done once a day, in the morning. She couldn't make enough money by just selling eggs. After joining DINARI Foundation, Komang S. obtained funding and training assistance on proper chicken farming techniques. Ni Komang is trying to apply her learning. The loan she obtains will be used to repair and expand the pen, so she can farm more chicken and feed more. At this time she has 50 egg producing hens and 5 roosters. She spends about $1.70 for feeds that consists of rice, corn and concentrate. She earns $4.44 a day by selling eggs. She may earn net profit of 2.75 per day. From this profit, Ni Komang S. can supplement income from her husband, Gusti Ketut Sumantri, and pay her 2 children's tuition. She plans to buy more chicken so she may increase her profit.

Translated from Indonesian by Kresna Hartandi, Kiva Volunteer

Ni Komang S. sudah terbiasa dengan memelihara ayam kampung. Semula hanya memelihara beberapa ekor saja. Ayam-ayam tersebut dibiarkan hidup bebas untuk mencari makan sendiri. Pemberian pakan hanya diberikan waktu pagi hari saja. Hasil telurnya pun masih belum maksimal. Dengan bergabung dengan Yayasan DINARI Ni Komang S. mendapat bantuan dana dan pembinaan budidaya ternak ayam secara baik. Ni Komang S. mencoba menerapkan apa yang sudah didapatkan dalam pembinaan dari Yayasan DINARI. Dengan dana tersebut kandang mulai diperbaiki dan diperbesar lagi, jumlah ayam diperbanyak , pemberian pakan pun dilakukan secara teratur. Saat ini jumlah ayam petelur sudah mencapai 50 ekor dan ayam pejantan 5 ekor. Biaya pakan dalam sehari mencapai Rp.15.000,-. Pakan ayam terdiri dedak padi, jagung dan konsetrat. Hasil penjulan telur dalam sehari dapat mencapai Rp. 40.000,- Keuntungan bersih dalam sehari mencapai Rp. 25.000,-. Dari keuntungan inilah Ni Komang S. dapat membantu penghasilan suaminya, Gusti Ketut Sumantri, dan dapat membiayai pendidikan kedua anaknya. Rencana kedepannya akan memperbanyak jumlah ayam peliharaanya, sehingga keuntungan dapat lebih meningkat lagi.

loans.use: Purchase Chicks to be Grown

payments.comment: Ni Komang sunistri finally repaid the rest of the loan. She had sold the chicken so she had more money. Now she has a plan to have another loan to improving her business. She want to rebuild the cage and buy chicks. She hope she will get it

loans.name: Thoeurn

texts.en:
Mrs. C. Thoeurn was married in 1993 and has 2 sons and 1 daughter. She has been in the business of planting vegetables since 1993, after she got married. In addition, in order to generate additional income for the household she started another business of raising pigs in 2006. Her husband, Mr. Sok Lay, is a farmer who grows rice in the village. They both did not finish primary school. However, they are working hard and have the ability to send their children to the local school.

She is requesting a loan from MAXIMA for the first time, in the amount of $500. She will use this money to purchase seeds, fertilizer and pesticide for planting vegetables, and also purchase feed for the pigs.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizer and pesticide, and feed for the pigs

loans.name: Euis

texts.en: Euis is 25 years old and is married with a 4-year-old child. She sells food such as noodles, rice, meat, fried snacks and other items. She usually earns $5 per day with a profit of $2.50 per day. Her husband is a driver and earns about $10 per week. Euis would like a loan of $75 (IDR 500,000) to buy more goods and expand her business. Euis hopes to use the increased income for her child's education.

loans.use: To buy more goods and expand her food business

loans.name: Nasiyat

texts.en: Nasiyat (her husband is pictured) began her business 4 years ago. She is 46 years old, married, and has six children. She lives with her family in Khachmaz region, in the Yeni-Hayat settlement. Her business gives her opportunities to provide for her family. She would like a loan of $825 to buy a cow. Nasiyat's family wants to improve their business and increase their income.

loans.use: Nasiyat would like to buy a cow.

payments.comment: Correction due to underpayment for business 23291

loans.name: Kate

texts.en:
Kate N. lives in Nansana, a rural village on the outskirts of Kampala Uganda. Her home is located off a small path that wanders past babies and children playing with mothers close by visiting with neighbors. Often the women gather on rolled out mats on the concrete stoops of their homes.

Kate is 50 years old, single, with 3 children and 2 dependents. On a bench in front of her home, she sells matooke ( a banana in the plantain family), onions, tomatoes and kyangwe, which is grown on vines in trees and is used as a scrub sponge when bathing. Across from where this picture was taken is a small plot of land, 20’ x 10’ where Kate grows her matooke. Under the banana trees she raises pumpkins. And within sight she has a space for pigs.

Kate would like one day to have enough matooke from her garden to sell as a wholesaler, but for now she plans to use her loan to buy more seeds and plants for her garden, so she can increase her produce for sale.

loans.use: Kate plans to use her loan to buy more seeds and plants for her garden. She will then sell the produce at her vegetable stand.

loans.name: Halima

texts.en:
HALIMA, a widow in her early forties, lives with her 4-year-old orphaned niece and supports her teenage son who is currently attending boarding school. A year ago, Halima opened a diner called “Mama Lishe Halima” (Swahili for Mama Halima’s Café), where she serves breakfast, lunch, and dinner from 7a.m. onward. Before this business, her income was dependent on selling clothes, but she found this business to be an unreliable source of income since her customers often did not pay her the full amount on the spot. As a result, she took out a loan and found the confidence in herself to start a new trade.

Halima’s diner now makes a profit of around $20 a day. The diner holds about 10 customers at a time, but people can eat outside as well. As business is currently going well, and she was able to pay back her first loan successfully, her hope is to take out another loan in order to begin serving French fry dishes. Halima currently hires a helper for half the day and has plans to hire another helper to be in charge of cooking the French fries. She also has plans of setting up umbrella booths in front of her diner where people can eat them.

Halima belongs to the group Dhahabu (Swahili for “gold”), which consists of 36 other members who keep each other accountable and insure one another in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To hire an additional helper and to set up outdoor umbrella booths for customers

payments.comment: Halima was able to pay back the rest of her loan before the end of her loan term.

loans.name: Yeti

texts.en: Yeti S. is 38 years old and married. She has a small shop where she sells snacks, food and drinks, and household products. She earns about $15 per day. Her husband is a driver and can earn $15 per day. Yeti would like a loan of   (IDR 500,000) to increase her business. She hopes to improve her income for her children's education. Yeti is a member of MBK and is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To increase business for her general store

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose K. lives in the rural village of Nansana on the outskirts of Kampala, Uganda. She has a tailoring business. During the day she has a sewing machine set on the concrete entrance to Debby’s Salon, located on the busy highway . At home she has another sewing machine. In is not uncommon for women tailors to have two machines: one for home and one on the street next to a business. In the picture you can see some of the fabric that she uses to make garments.
 
She is a new client and has only been in her lending group for one month. Generally, a person needs to be in the lending group for at least a month before there are eligible for a loan. With her loan she plans to buy another machine and some fabric. She wants another machine because she is planning on starting a sewing school for young girls. Young girls often have to drop out of school to take care of sick parents, so a sewing school gives them a trade in which to earn a living.

loans.use: Rose plans to use her loan to buy another sewing machine and some fabric to start a sewing school.

loans.name: Ni Kadek

texts.id:
After marrying Putu Eka Susanta, Ni Kadek A. started a small kiosk in front of her home. SHe chose this business since there were no other kiosks in the neighborhood. SHe sells vatious snack items, ice, coffee, etc. Every day, Ni Kadek A. opens the kiosk at 7 am and closes at 6 pm. SInce the kiosk is in front of her home, Ni Kadek A. cna still take on additional small projects when business is quiet. Ni Kadek A. joined DINARI Foundation to get funding and training assistance on the advice of her sister. The loan will be used to increase her kiosk's working capital so she can offer more goods and increase the variety of her offerings. With $175 loan, Ni Kadek A. expects to increase her profit up to $2 a day. She hopes this business would expand faster in the future.

Translated from Indonesian by Kresna Hartandi, Kiva Volunteer

Setelah menikah dengan Putu Eka Susanta, suaminya, Ni Kadek A. mulai membuka warung kecil di depan rumahnya. Usaha ini dipilih karena tempat dimana Ni Kadek A. tinggal, tidak ada usaha warung yang menjadi saingannya. Barang yang dijual aneka macam makanan kecil , es, kopi dan lain - lain. Setiap hari Ni Kadek A. membuka warung pada pukul 07.00 wita dan tutup pada pukul 18.00 wita. Karena warung ada didepan rumahnya maka Ni Kadek A. dapat mengambil pekerjaan dirumahnya apabila warung tidak ada pelanggan. Melalui informasi dari saudaranya Ni Kadek A. akhirnya bergabung dengan Yayasan DINARI dan menjadi salah satu binaannya dan mendapat dana pinjaman. Dengan dana tersebut dipakai untuk menambah modal usaha warungnya. Menambah dan melengkapi jenis variasi jenis barang dagangannya. Dengan pinjaman Rp.1.500.000.- Ni Kadek A. dapat memperoleh keuntungan bersih mencapai Rp.20.000,- setiap harinya. Usaha warung ini ditekuninya dengan harapan kedepannya warung dapat lebih meningkat dan lebih besar lagi.

loans.use: Increase capital to increase shop offering

payments.comment: Finally she can repaid the rest of the loan. The business really help her economic life and can help her family to run this life. The loan that she had help her to improved her business. Now after finished repaid the loan, she has a plan to get another loan. She will use it to improving her business. She hope she will get the next loan soon.

loans.name: Wiwin

texts.en: Wiwin is 38 years old and married. She has a business selling clothes on credit, which she does by going door to door to reach new customers. Her husband, Supratman, has no fixed income at the moment and does odd jobs. She would like a loan of $75 (IDR 500,000) to buy more clothes for resale. She earns about $16 per week. Wiwin hopes this loan will allow her to increase her income for herself and her husband. She is a member of MBK and is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business

loans.name: Deborah

texts.en:
Deborah N. owns Debby’s Salon where she has run her hair styling business for 12 years. Her salon sits about 75’ back from the busy highway. On busy highways, buildings tend to sit back. That area between the highway and the buildings is always filled with activity. People cooking on small charcoal stoves, matatoo’s, taxis, stopping to drop off and pick up new customers, boda boda’s, motorbikes, waiting to take paying customers and just a constant flow of people.
Deborah’s business has a good location and a good clientele. As with many hair salons all over the world, it is place for women to visit, sit with their babies and pass the time. 
With her loan, Deborah plans to buy a generator. This is a big and important purchase, as electricity goes out quite regularly. Clients will tend to go to places that have back-up power.  She has a well stocked salon and is a very welcoming individual.

loans.use: Deborah plans to use her loan to buy a generator, so when the electricity goes out her clients won't be without a hair dryer.

loans.name: Erni

texts.en: Erni is 22 years old and is married with a 2-year-old child. She sells clothes on credit and usually earns $20 per month. She also sells soap and cosmetics, and goes door to door to sell her products. Her husband, Manan, has no fixed income at the moment and does odd jobs. She is a member of MBK and would like a loan of $75 (IDR 500,000) to expand her business and sell a wider variety of goods. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To buy more inventory for her business

loans.name: Lun

texts.en:
Mrs. R. Lun was married in 1975 and has 4 sons and 5 daughters. She started her farming business in 1990. She plants vegetables and bananas. In addition, she also raises a few cows at home. Her husband also farms with his wife and looks after the cows.

She has borrowed money from MAXIMA three times. She is now requesting a loan in the amount of $900. She will use this money to purchase a cow to raise and use in her farming activities.

loans.use: To purchase a cow

loans.name: Neman

texts.en: Neman has been in this business for one year. He is 21 years old and single. He lives in Khachmaz town. He would like to improve the conditions of his cafe to attract more clients, therefore he is applying for a loan of $825 to buy glasses, teapots, kettles and sugar-bowls.

loans.use: Neman would like to buy glasses, teapots, kettles and sugar-bowls for his cafe.

payments.comment: Correction due to underpayment for business 23301

loans.name: Oon

texts.en: Oon is 45 years old and married. She produces and sells flavored ice sticks at her house and and also consigns them  at small shops. She also sells other cooked items--fried snacks and rice in banana leaves--and earns $15 per day. She would like a loan of $100 (IDR 900,000) to expand her business by selling a wider variety of flavored ice sticks, flavored milk, and other snacks. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To expand her inventory of food items for sale

loans.name: Pendo

texts.en:
PENDO, age 27, was a kindergarten teacher until she had her second child 9 months ago. Seeing that her teacher’s salary would not be enough to support her household, which includes her younger sister, 2 children, and an assistant, she left teaching and began selling merchandise door-to-door. She sells new handbags, shoes, bed sheets, and fabrics, and makes about $10-$14 a day from this trade. From the profits, she opened a small snack shop 3 months ago and now hires a shop assistant so that she can continue selling door-to-door. The shop brings in a profit of around $3-$5 a day. With her savings and a new loan, Pendo hopes to open a new business, a café.

Pendo belongs to the group Dhahabu (Swahili for “gold”), which consists of 36 other members who keep each other accountable and insure one another in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To open a café

payments.comment: Pendo has paid back her loan successfully before the end of the loan term.

loans.name: Kosal

texts.en:
Mrs. I. Kosal is a widow with 2 sons. She learned to weave silk from her neighbor in 1980 and started her silk production in the same year. Recently, one of her sons began assisting her in weaving silk at home, while the other son works in a restaurant in Phnom Penh. After borrowing money from MAXIMA again and again, her living is getting better. Now, she plans to set up another loom for her son.

She has borrowed money from MAXIMA six times previously. Now, she is asking for a loan of $500. She will use this loan to purchase silk materials and sewing thread, and pay fees for selecting and preparing silk on the looms. She will also use the loan to set up another loom for her son.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials and sewing thread, and pay fees for selecting and preparing silk on the looms. Also, to set up another loom for her son.

loans.name: Margadlene

texts.en:
Margadlene N. has a tailoring business in Nansana, a rural village on the outskirts of Kampala, Uganda.  She has operated her business for the past 35 years and is well known in her community. Her home is made of brick with a well swept dirt floor.

Margadlene is married with 5 children and she takes care of 2 orphans.  Almost without exception, the entrepreneurs of businesses are caring for not only their own children but also for the children of their deceased brothers or sisters. This is the effect of AID’s on the communities of Uganda. Uganda has done a lot to improve the problem. From a high of 33% of the people infected to currently only 5%, they can be commended for their efforts. Still the effects are evident in the orphaned children.

With her loan, Margadlene plans to buy more fabric and embroidery for her business. She hopes that one day she will be able to involve her children in the business. But this is difficult as most businesses can only hope to support one person.

loans.use: Margadlene plans to use her loan to buy more fabric and embroidery for her tailoring business.

loans.name: Ita

texts.en: Ita is 36 years old and is married. She sells fried snacks by going around the village everyday. She has to work to supplement her family's income. She usually earns $5 per day and it is not enough for her family's needs. Her husband sells herbs and makes a small income. She is asking for a IDR 1,000,000 loan to complete her business, and hopes that this will improve her daily income. Ita is a member of MBK and is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To complete her business

loans.name: Ni Luh Sutamiasih

texts.id:
Ni Luh Sutamiasih makes and sells "Red Sugar." She obtains the ingredients from her husband, Ketut Kicen who seeks coconut honey for her to process. She obtains the ingredients from her small coconut plantation, and she also buys some coconut honey from her neighbor. She makes the "red sugar" at home. After all ingredients are combined in a pot, it was heated to concentrate the mixture. Then it was placed on a cast and cooled. Then the red sugar was ready. Besides producing her own "Red sugar," Ni Luh Sutamiasih buys "red sugar" from her neighbors too to be resold to wholesaler. To increase her red sugar dealing, Ni Luh Sutamiasih joined DINARI, where she expected to obtain funding and training assistance. She earns about $33 in revenue and gets about $3 profit. She hopes to be able to support her three children with the additional income from the business.

Translated from Indonesian by Kresna Hartandi, Kiva Volunteer

Membuat gula merah adalah menjadi pekerjaan sehari - hari bagi Ni Luh Sutamiasih. Bahan baku didapat dari suaminya, Ketut Kicen, yang setiap hari mencari tuak kelapa ( sari dari bunga pohon kelapa ) yang sebagai bahan dasar . Bahan didapat dari kebun kelapa miliknya, dan didapat dengan bekerja sama dengan pemilik pohon kelapa langganannnya yang sudah biasa diambil tuaknya. Proses pembuatan gula merah dilakukan sendiri dirumahnya. Setelah bahan baku dikumpulkan dalam satu wadah, kemudian dipanaskan sampai mengental, setelah pada kepekatan tertentu kemudian adonan tersebut di letakan pada sebuah cetakan dan dibiarkan sampai dingin , jadilah gula merah dan siap untuk di perjualbelikan Selain membuat gula merah sendiri, Ni Luh Sutamiasih setiap hari berkeliling kepada masyarakat untuk membeli gula merah. Untuk menambah modal usaha berjual beli gula merah Ni Luh Sutamiasih bergabung dengan DINARI . Selain mendapat modal Ni Luh Sutaiasih juga mendapat pembinaan. Pendapatan setiap harinya dapat mencapai Rp. 300.000,- dengan keuntungan bersih mencapai Rp.30.000,-. Dengan hasih jerih payahnya itu Ni Luh Sutamiasih dapat membiaya ketiga anaknya, dan dipakai untuk keperluan setip harinya.

loans.use: Purchase "red sugar" from farmers to be resold

payments.comment: Finally she can repaid the rest of the loan. The business really help her economic life and can help her family to run this life. The loan that she had help her to improved her business. Now after finished repaid the loan, she has a plan to get another loan. She will use it to improving her business. She hope she will get the next loan soon.

loans.name: Chanthol

texts.en:
Miss N. Chanthol is currently living with her elderly parents. She learned to weave silk from her neighbor in 2001 and began her silk production in the same year. Her sister also weaves silk at home with another loom. Her father is in the farming business, and he plants bananas and raises cows in the village. Her mother stays at home.

She has borrowed money from MAXIMA three times. Now, she is asking for a loan of $500. She will use this loan to purchase wood supplies to repair her house.

loans.use: To purchase wood supplies to repair her house.

loans.name: Neneng

texts.en: Neneng is 37 years old and is married with one child aged 3. She sells clothes on credit and goes door to door to reach new customers. Her husband sells cakes at the market and makes a small income. She needs a IDR 900,000 loan to buy more clothes and the rest will be used for her husband's business. She usually earns $10 per day. Neneng hopes this loan will allow her to help her husband and supplement their incomes. She's a member of MBK and is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To buy more clothes

loans.name: Geofrey

texts.en:
Geofrey  M. is a young looking 37 year old man with wife and 4 children. He is entrepreneurial and business-like. When asked what he hopes for, he said he would like to be a big business man so he can better provide for his family. 

Geofrey has a well stocked retail store where he sells food stuffs such as posho (maize flour), sugar, salt and cooking oil. He has operated the business for 5 years and has been with his lending group for 4 years. With his loan he plans to increase his inventory so that he will have the best stocked store in Nansana.

loans.use: Geofrey plans to use his loan to buy more sugar, salt, cooking oil and maize flour for his food store.

loans.name: Mamah

texts.en: Mamah is 40 years old and is married. She sells clothes on credit and goes door to door to sell her products. She usually earns $10 per day. Her husband sells clothes in the market. She needs more capital to expand her business, due to the small profit margin of her husband's clothes business. Mamah is a member of MBK and requests a IDR 900,000 loan. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Heng

texts.en:
Mr. P. Heng was married in 1979, and he has 2 sons and 5 daughters. He is currently in the business of farming, fishing, and planting soy beans. He started the farming business in 2004. Before that, he worked as a construction worker. His wife assists him in planting the soy beans. They both did not finish primary school. Four of his children live under his care, and three children are married and living in separate houses with their families. Two daughters work at the garment factory and two children are studying.

He has borrowed money from MAXIMA five times previously. He is now requesting a loan in the amount of $1,000. He will use this money to purchase a fishing net and baby fish to feed.

loans.use: To purchase a fishing net and baby fish.

loans.name: Touch

texts.en:
Mrs. S. Touch was married in 1989 and has 3 sons and 1 daughter. She started her business of selling grocery items in 2002. Her husband is in the farming business of growing rice. In addition, he is also a cook for wedding ceremonies. With the grocery store and farming business, they are able to send their children to the local school.

She is now requesting a loan from MAXIMA for the first time, in the amount of $250. She will use this money to purchase more grocery items for her stock in order to expand her grocery business.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items for her stock.

payments.comment:
Dear lender,

Mrs. Touch Sann paid off her loan early before contract.

Thank you.

loans.name: Sarwati

texts.en: Sarwati is 45 years old and is married with one son. Her husband passed away and now she is working on her own. She started her business after she became a member of MBK. She needs a IDR 1,000,000 loan, and intends to use it for buying fertilizer and seeds for her farm.
