Sarwati usually earns $10 per day and she hopes that the loan will help her business generate more income. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and seeds for her farm

loans.name: Yoeurn

texts.en:
Mrs. M. Yoeurn has 4 children: 1 son and 3 daughters. She started her pig-raising business in 2003. Her husband serves as a member of the PREK Taten commune council. Their 3 daughters work at the garment factory in Pon-nhea Leu district.

She is requesting a loan from MAXIMA for the first time, in the amount of $1,000. She will use this money to purchase more baby pigs to expand her business. Meanwhile, she also will use some of the amount to buy wood supplies to repair her house.

loans.use: To purchase more baby pigs and buy wood supplies to repair her house.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Aas

texts.en: Aas is 25 years old and is married. She has a small shop which sells snacks, and a few household items. She usually earns $7 per day, with a small profit. Her husband is a motorcycle taxi driver and can earn $2 per day. Aas needs a IDR 1,000,000 loan to buy more goods and complete her shop. She's a member of MBK and is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To buy more goods and complete her shop

loans.name: Sophia

texts.en:
SOPHIA, age 26, is the owner of "Teddy Salon," which was named after her sister. Living at home with her mother, 8-year-old daughter, and 17-year-old orphaned niece, Sopia helps to support her home through the profits of her 2-year-old business. Before opening the salon, Sophia worked for two years providing hairdressing services from within her home. Now, with her own salon, she is able make around $36 a day, or more, depending on the season. From a small previous loan, Sophia was able to pay the rent and cover general expenses. Now, having successfully paid this back, she hopes to take out another loan to buy hair treatments and accessories to expand her services.

Sophia belongs to the group Dhahabu (Swahili for “gold”), which consists of 36 other members who keep each other accountable and insure one another in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy hair treatments and accessories to expand salon services

payments.comment: Sophia was able to pay the remaining of her loan before the end of her loan term.

loans.name: Nurhayati

texts.en: Nurhayati is 23 years old and is married with one child aged 1. She has a small shop which sells snacks, food, and drinks, along with household products. She can earn $6 per day. Her husband has no fixed income. She would like a IDR 900,000 loan to complete her business. Nurhayati hopes that she can improve her income to use towards her children's education. She is a member of MBK and is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To complete her business

loans.name: Chantha

texts.en:
Mr. L. Chantha was married in 2000 and has 3 children: 2 sons and 1 daughter. He started his business of producing fresh noodles, and selling to the local market, in 1995. He learned his business from his neighbor. His wife and two children also assist him with producing the fresh noodles. One of his sons studies at the local school. Besides making fresh noodles, Mr. Chantha and his wife farm as well.

He is requesting a loan from MAXIMA for the first time, in the amount of US$500. He will use this loan to purchase a motorbike and carriage to transport the noodles to sell in the market, so that he can expand his production and generate more income to support the family.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike and carriage to transport the noodles to sell in the market.

loans.name: Umyati

texts.en: Umyati is 40 years old and is married. She produces cakes and sells them by going around the village. At home, she sells flavoured ice sticks, and can earn $5 per day. Her husband has no fixed income. Umyati is requesting a IDR 1,000,000 loan to expand her business in order to supplement their income. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Somaly

texts.en:
Mrs. I. Somaly was married in 1983 and has 3 children: one son and two daughters. She started her grocery business in 2001. Her two daughters work at the garment factory. Only her son is in primary school in the village. Her husband is a government official, and he is currently working in the Ministry of Social Affairs, Veteran and Youth Rehabilitation.

She has borrowed money from MAXIMA five times. Now, she is requesting a loan in the amount of $400. She will use this loan to purchase more grocery items for her stock so that she can expand her grocery business.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery items for her stock.

loans.name: Elih

texts.en: Elih is 30 years old and is married. She sells cosmetics on credit and usually earns $10 per week. Her husband, Dahlan, is a driver, and usually earns $40 per month. Elih is requesting a IDR 500,000 loan to expand her business. Elih hopes that she can improve her income to use towards her children's education. She is a member of MBK and is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Sokhem

texts.en:
Mrs. N. Sokhem was married in 1980 and has 5 daughters. She started her grocery business in 1995. Her two daughters work at the garment factory, and her other three daughters study at the primary school in the village. Her husband runs a transportation service. He is currently transporting garment workers from their villages to the factory. Both Sokhem and her husband did not finish high school. However, they are working hard to help their children go to school.

She has borrowed money from MAXIMA twice already. Now, she is requesting a loan in the amount of $700. She will use this loan to purchase more grocery items for her stock in order to expand her grocery business.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery items for her stock

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Korn

texts.en:
Mr. K. Korn was married in 1969 and has 4 children, 3 sons and one daughter. He has been in the business of fishing since 1979. He started fishing in 1970, which he learned from his older generation. His eldest son assists him with his fishing business. One of his sons and a daughter work at the garment factory, while the youngest son is studying. His wife works growing rice.

He has borrowed money from MAXIMA five times already. Now, he is requesting a loan in the amount of $1,200. He will use this loan to purchase farm machinery and an ox cart in order to expand the family rice production.

loans.use: To purchase farm machinery and an ox cart.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Vina

texts.en:
Mrs. N. Vina is single and currently living with her old father in Puk Rosey village. She learned to weave silk from her elder sister in 2001 and started her silk production in the same year. Before that time, she had learned to sew and also has the ability to make clothes. Her father is a farmer, and he grows rice and other food crops.

She has borrowed money from MAXIMA twice already. Now, she is asking for a loan of $500. She will use this loan to purchase silk materials, sewing thread, and pay fees for selecting and preparing silk on the looms for her silk production.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials, sewing thread, and pay fees for selecting and preparing silk on the looms.

loans.name: Mao

texts.en:
Mrs. Mao Y. was married in 1992 and three children, two sons and one daughter. Her husband runs a business fishing and growing rice and other crops which he sells at the local market. Mao Y. herself has her own business weaving silk. Mao Y.'s neighbour taught her how to weave silk in 1990 and she began her own silk production in the same year. 

She has borrowed money from MAXIMA five times previously. She is now requesting this loan of $500 to purchase silk materials and sewing thread.

loans.use: to purchase silk materials and sewing thread

loans.name: Jeremia

texts.en:
JEREMIA, age 24, opened his shop three years ago. Before this, he sold items while walking on the street. Now his shop carries luggage, clothes, and shoes. Around 40 customers come by the shop each day and bring in a profit of around $18. With the profits, Jeremia pays the rent and the salary of a shop assistant– his nephew and roommate. He also financially supports his parents and 4 siblings who are in school. Jeremia hopes to take out a loan to increase his inventory.

Jeremia belongs to the group Tujikwamue (Swahili for “progressing from one stage to another”), which consists of 25 other members who keep each other accountable and insure one another in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To increase inventory

payments.comment: Jeremia was able to pay his loan back successfully before the end of the loan term!

loans.name: Sokmeng

texts.en:
Miss. Sokmeng Path is single and currently living with her father. She learned to weave silk from her elder sister in 1998 and started her silk production in the same year. She also trained her younger sister who is living in the same house to weave as well. Her mother now sews clothes in their home which she sells to people in her community. Sokmeng Path's father is a farmer. He  currently grows rice and other food crops to sell in the village. He would like to increase the family's income by running a horse and cart business, which will transport people and their goods to the market. 

This is the first time Sokmeng Path has applied for a loan with MAXIMA. She has asked for this $500 in order to purchase one horse so that her father can run the transportation service.

loans.use: to purchase one horse for her father so that he can run a business

payments.comment:
Dear lender,

Miss. Sokmeng Parth has enough money to pay off her loan. Thank you.

loans.name: Kim-Oeurn

texts.en:
Mr. Kim-oeurn C. was married in 1985 and has 5 children, 4 sons and 1 daughter. He learnt to repair radios, TVs and tape recorders after he married, and he started his business repairing radios, TVs and tape recorders in 1986. His wife brings in additional income selling Chinese noodles and coffee from their house. Neither husband nor wife finished primary school. With the income from their businesses however, the couple are able to send all of their children to school.

This is the first time Kim-Oueurn C. has asked for a loan from MAXIMA. He has asked for this $300 in order to purchase more music tools and materials so that he can expand his business repairing radios, TVs, and tape recorders.

loans.use: to purchase more tools and materials in order to expand his business

loans.name: Sakinakhanim

texts.en: Sakinakhanim (her husband is pictured) is the mother of three children. One year ago her family started this business. Sakinakhanim is 53 years old and she lives in the Khachmaz region, in the village of Garagurtlu. Now they need a loan of $825 to buy fertilizer and pesticides to improve their orchard and then they will be able to meet all demands of their family.

loans.use: Sakinakhanim would like to buy fertilizer and pesticides for her orchard.

payments.comment: Correction due to underpayment for business 23330

loans.name: Neneng

texts.en: Neneng is 40 years old and is married. She sells kerosene and usually earns $5 per day. Her husband, M. Yusuf, is a driver with a salary of $10 per week. She is requesting a IDR 500,000 loan to complete her business. Neneng hopes that this will allow her business to improve and prosper. She is a member of MBK and is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To complete her business

loans.name: Lalin

texts.en:
Mrs. Lalin S. was married in 2004 and now has 1 daughter. She started her business raising chickens in 2005. She now also cooks food which she sells from her home for additional income. Her husband is an English teacher in the local school and runs a business repairing air-conditioners. 

She is requesting a loan from MAXIMA for the first time. She would like this $600  to expand her chicken raising business and to repair her house.

loans.use: to expand her chicken raising business and repair her house

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Heng

texts.en:
Mrs. Heng T. was married in 1988 and has 4 children, 3 sons and 1 daughter. In 2004 her mother taught her to weave silk, and she has been weaving ever since. She has also trained her younger sister, who lives with them, how to weave. Her husband runs a business repairing people's televisions. In addition, the family runs a business ploughing the fields of people in their community. Neither husband nor wife finished high school, but with their current business they are supporting all four children through school. 

Heng T. has borrowed money from MAXIMA twice before. She is now asking for a loan of $500, which she will use to purchase one more cow and expand the family's ploughing business.

loans.use: to purchase one more cow for her business

payments.comment:
Dear lender,

Mrs. Heng Thuch has pay off her loan early before contract and requesting a new loan from Maxima for continuing her existing business.

Thank you.

loans.name: Kea

texts.en:
Mrs. Kea M. was married in 2004 and now has one daughter. She learned to weave silk from her mother in 2003 and started her silk production in 2005 after she was married. She trained her husband to weave as well, and he can now assist her in weaving silk at home. 

This is the first time she has asked for a loan from MAXIMA. She has asked for $300 to purchase silk materials, sewing thread and to purchase another loom for her husband so that they can weave more silk and expand their business.

loans.use: to purchase silk materials, sewing thread, and an extra loom

payments.comment:
Dear lender,
Mrs. Kea Mean had off her loan already. Thank you.

loans.name: Sukmariah

texts.en: Sukmariah is 37 years old and she's married. She sells some snacks and beverages in a small shop. She usually earns an income of $10/day.  Since she has become a member of MBK, her income has eventually increased.  She would like to have a IDR 900,000 loan to complete her shop. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To complete her shop

loans.name: Thi Chuyen

texts.vi:
Ms Chuyên is a hard working, responsible person. She is 40 years old, married with 3 young children. They live in "Trung Bạn" hamlet, near the town of "Chờ", Yên Phong, in the province of "Bắc Ninh". In the past, she used to sell waste material (glass, glass bottles, metal) to recycling companies for a living. Everyday, she would go to town, doing door to door to buy glass & metal material then she would resell. She made about 2.50 USD a day (40000 VND). Her husband works in construction, his salary helps cover part of the expenses of the family. But the income from both of them is not enough and it is unstable so they have decided to put all their savings and borrow some money from their family members to buy chickens to raise. Every year, their peep of chickens grows. They sell 2 batches of chickens a year, these chickens are replaced by new chicks from their own chicken hatchery. Today they have about 100 chickens and this is their pride and happiness for the family. They request a loan to buy chicken feed. They will be able to pay back the loan in 6 months

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer

Chị Chuyên là người phụ nữ chịu khó, đảm đang. Chị 40 tuổi đã có chồng và 3 con nhỏ. Chị sống ở Thôn Trung Bạn, Thị trấn Chờ, Yên Phong, Bắc Ninh. Trước đây, chị kiếm sống bằng nghề thu mua đồng nát (ve chai). Hàng ngày, chị gánh đôi quang gánh đi khắp nơi trong thị trấn để thu mua đồng nát, sắt vụn, sau đó bán lại cho các cơ sở mua buôn. Mỗi ngày chị cũng kiếm được khoảng 30-40.000 VND. Chồng chị làm thợ xây cũng hỗ trợ được thêm thu nhập cho gia đình. Tuy nhiên, mức thu nhập quá bấp bênh và không đủ sống như vậy nên anh chị đã quyết định gom góp tất cả vốn liếng của mình và đi vay mượn thêm của những người thân trong gia đình để mua gà về nuôi. Mỗi năm, đàn gà của anh chị lại nhiều thêm và trung bình mỗi năm chị có thể bán đi 2 lứa và nuôi thêm những lứa mới từ việc cho ấp nở tại nhà. Hiện tại đàn gà của anh chị đã có khoảng trên 100 con và đó là niềm vui rất lớn của cả gia đình. Anh chị đang mong muốn có thêm một khoản tiền để hỗ trợ trong việc mua thức ăn cho gà. Anh chị sẽ có đủ khả năng để thanh toán khoản vay trong vòng 6 tháng.

loans.use: To purchase food for chickens

loans.name: Visith

texts.en:
Mr. Visith A. was married in 2005 and now has one daughter. He runs a business planting papaya.  He also assists with silk weaving at home after learning from his wife. His wife first learnt how to weave silk when her mother taught her in 1998, and she has been weaving ever since. 

This is the first time he has asked for a loA. from MAXIMA. He has asked for this $500 to purchase more silk and sewing thread for his wife. Now he cA. weave well himself he would like to set up another loom for himself. With the money that is left over he will buy more papaya seeds to plant in his farmland.

loans.use: to purchase silk materials, sewing thread and another loom for himself.  He will purchase papaya seeds for his farmland with the remaining money

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Yin

texts.en:
Mrs. Yin T. was married in 1990 and has four children, one son and three daughters. In 2004 she started her business making and selling fish sausages. He husband helps her with this business, and he also raises ducks at home.

She has borrowed money from MAXIMA twice before already. She is now asking for a loan of $700. She will use this loan to expand her fish sausage making business by purchasing another fish sausage making machine. She would also like to buy 100 baby ducks to raise at home.

loans.use: to buy another fish sausage making machine and a 100 baby ducks

loans.name: Nuriah

texts.en: Nuriah is 30 years old and she's married. Her business is that she makes gifts look like parcels (presents) and she can earn more income at special times like the festive season. She usually earns an income of $20/parcel. Her husband, Hidayat has no fixed income and only does odd jobs. She would like to have a IDR 900,000 loan to complete her shop. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To complete her shop

loans.name: Keath

texts.en:
Mr. Keat H. was married in 1989 and has four children, one son and three daughters. He runs a business making beds which he sells to local people. Meanwhile, he and his wife also grow cucumber, corn and vegetables on his farm land.

He is requesting a loan from MAXIMA for the first time. He has asked for this $600 to purchase wood so that he can increase the amount of beds he can sell.

loans.use: to purchase wood for making beds to sell to local people

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Sophal

texts.en:
Mr. Sophal L. is single. He is currently living with his sister, Miss. Maly L. in Prek Samrong village of Ta Khmao district. Both are orphan children. Since 2005 Sophal L. has run his motor taxi business in Phnom Penh. He works L. days and returns home very late at night. His sister is working in a garment factory in Ta Khmao district. 

This is the first time Sophal L. has requested a loan from MAXIMA. He is asking for $500 to purchase a new motorbike so that he can save money in the L. run by not having to repair his existing bike quite so often.

loans.use: to buy a new motorbike

payments.comment:
Dear lender,

Mr. Sophal Long has enough money to pay off his loan.
Thank you.

loans.name: Herlis

texts.en: Herlis is 31 years old and is married. She sells rice and some fried foods such as fried chicken, potatoes, fish, fried snacks, and many more items. Her husband, Paman has no fixed income and only does odd jobs. Herlis has been running her business since she joined MBK, and can earn $17 per day. She needs a IDR 900,000 loan for buying some foods and to increase her capital. She hopes that this will increase her business and she is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To increase her capital

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mrs. H. Mary is married in 1980 and has 4 children, one son and 3 daughters. She is running a cleaning motorbike station since 2005. Her husband is also assisting her in this business. Her husband, Mr. Samrith Chith is a cooker for the wedding ceremony. Two of their children are living under their custody and the other two daughters are married and have moved to live in different house.   

She is requesting a loan from MAXIMA for the first time with the amount of $1,100. She will use this loan to purchase another cleaning machine and repairing house.

loans.use: Purchasing another cleaning machine and repairing house.

loans.name: Afgan

texts.en: Afgan is 29 years old, married, has one child. This young man lives in Khachmaz region, in the Ashagi-Zeyid village. He has been in the cattle breeding business for 10 years. Now he needs a loan of $825 to buy one cow.

loans.use: Afgan would like to buy one cow.

payments.comment: Correction due to underpayment for business 23344

loans.name: Ma'anih

texts.en: Ma'anih is 45 years old and she's married. Her business is selling household goods such as cooking oil, rice, snacks,  eggs, etc. Her husband has no fixed income. Ma'anih usually earns $1.50 per day in profit.  She is a member of MBK and needs IDR 500,000 loan to complete her shop. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To complete her shop

loans.name: Sour

texts.en:
Mr. Sour E. was married in 1979 and has 6 children, 4 sons and 2 daughters. Since 2002 he has run a business renting a microphone and a generator for various kinds of ceremonies. His wife runs another business, planting and selling flowers. Neither husband nor wife completed primary education. Three of their sons are married and have moved to live in different houses. The fourth helps his mother in planting flowers for the business, while the remaining two daughters are working in a garment factory 

He is requesting a loan from MAXIMA for the first time with for the amount of $500. He will use this loan to purchase another generator to expand his existing hiring business.

loans.use: to purchase another generator to expand his existing hiring business.

loans.name: Sorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Sorn C. was married in 1979 and now has 9 children, 4 sons and 5 daughters. Since she was married she has run her own business, planting and selling vegetables. Her husband is a construction contractor. When he is free from the construction work he also assists his wife in planting vegetables. With these businesses they can earn enough money to send their children to attend school. Six of their children are living under their custody and are studying at school. The remaining three children were married and moved to live in different houses.      

She has borrowed money from MAXIMA twice before. Now she is asking a loan of $1,200. She will use this loan to purchase fertilizer, pesticide and a covering net.

loans.use: to purchase ertilizer, pesticide and covering net.

loans.name: Yeti

texts.en: Yeti is 45 years old and is married. To supplement her husband's income, Yeti runs a playstation rental in her house, and Yeti can earn $3 per day. Her husband, Syaripudin has no fixed income.  Yeti is a member of MBK and is asking for a IDR 900,000 loan to expand her business. She hopes to earn more income to use for her children's education. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Pipih

texts.en: Pipih is 32 years old and is married. She sells clothes on credit and goes door to door to sell her products. She usually earns $15 per day. Her husband sells clothes in the market too. She needs more capital to expand her business, due to the small profit margin of her husband's clothes business. Pipih is a member of MBK and requests a IDR 1,000,000 loan. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mrs. Mary H. was married in 1980 and now has four children, one son and three daughters. Since 2005 she has run a motorbike cleaning station. Her husband assists her with this business when he has time off from his main job, working as a cook for wedding ceremonies. Two of their children live with them and the other two daughters are married and have moved to live in a different house.   

She is requesting a loan from MAXIMA for the first time for $1,100. She will use this loan to purchase another cleaning machine and to repair the house.

loans.use: to purchase another cleaning machine and to repair the house

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Thi Thuyet

texts.vi:
Ms Thuyết, 48 years old, is married and has 2 children. Her husband is a construction worker. Ms Thuyết learned how to make bean curd (tofu) from her mother in law. Everyday she's up at dawn to make fresh bean curd then she would sell it at the local market. Now all her bean curd making tools are so used, they need to be upgraded. Thuyết was planning to buy new tools in order to keep up with the production increase and also to assure the quality of her bean curd. When she learned of binhminh cdc, she applied for a loan. She plans to repay in 6 months. She would put aside part of the profit from the sale of bean curd plus part of her husband salary to pay back the loan.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer

Chị Thuyết 48 tuổi có chồng làm thợ xây và có 2 con. Chị lấy chồng và có được nghề làm đậu phụ từ gia đình nhà chồng. Hàng ngày chị làm đậu từ sáng sớm và mang ra chợ bán. Sau một thời gian dài sản xuất nên hầu hết dụng cụ làm đậu đã trở nên cũ và không phù hợp nữa. Chị đang dự định mua mới một số dụng cụ để làm đậu được ngon và hiệu quả hơn. Được biết có chương trình cho vay vốn của binhminh cdc, chị đã đăng ký vay vốn với thời gian là 6 tháng. Chị dự định sẽ dùng một phần tiền lãi từ việc bán đậu và một phần thu nhập của chồng để trả vốn vay hàng tuần cho khoản vay này

loans.use: To purchase tool to make bean curd

loans.name: Nazima

texts.en: Nazima (her husband is pictured) is the mother of two children. This family lives in the Khachmaz region in the Hadjiisa-Oba village. She is 41 years old. Nazima has 2 years of experience in the dairy business. Now her family is applying for a loan of $825 to buy a cow for getting more milk and increasing their income.

loans.use: Nazima would like to buy a cow.

payments.comment: Correction due to underpayment for business 23352

loans.name: Van Bac

texts.vi:
Mr Bắc is 34 years old, married with 1 kid who's attending 4th grade. Both he and his wife have occupation. She sells peanuts and he raises poultry. They have about 70-90 chickens. He plans to repair the chicken coop: to solidify and clean up the environment. He had applied for a loan and plans to repay it in 6 months. He will put aside a portion of his income to make the monthly payment.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer

Anh Bắc 34 tuổi, có vợ và có 1 con đang học lớp 4. Cả hai anh chị đều có công việc để kiếm sống. Vợ anh là chị Hoàn làm đậu phụ để bán. Anh chủ yếu tập trung vào chăm sóc đàn gà khoảng 70-80 con của gia đình. Hiện tại anh đang muốn sửa chữa lại trại gà của mình cho sạch sẽ và kiên cố hơn. Anh hiện đã đăng ký vay vốn và trả dần trong vòng 6 tháng. Thu nhập của gia đình sẽ được tiết kiệm để hoàn vốn vay.

loans.use: To repair chicken farm

loans.name: Adil

texts.en: Adil has his own orchard. He has been in this business for 3 years. He is 54 years old, married, and has two children. He lives in the Khachmaz region, in the village of Gusarchay. Now he needs a loan of $725 to buy fertilizer and pesticide for improving his orchard.

loans.use: Adil would lik to buy fertilizer and pesticides for his orchard.

payments.comment: Correction due to overpayment for business 23354

loans.name: Mehti

texts.en: Ten years ago Mehti started this business. This 30-year-old man is single, lives in Khachmaz region, in the Ashagi-Zeyid village. Now he needs a loan of $725 to buy a cow to improve his cattle business.

loans.use: Mehti would like to buy one cow.

loans.name: Dastagul

texts.en: Dastagul (her husband is pictured) is the mother of three children. This 51 year-old woman lives with her family in Khachmaz region, in the Gobu-Girag village. This family has been in this business for 8 years. Now they need a loan of $725 to buy a cow to improve their business.

loans.use: Dastagul would like to buy a cow.

loans.name: Zaur

texts.en: Zaur is 32 years old, married and has a child. Three years ago he decided to be taxi driver. He has a lot of clients. He is trying to improve his business by providing better service to his clients. Now he needs a loan of $725 to buy spare parts to improve his taxi.

loans.use: Zaur would like to buy spare parts for his taxi.

loans.name: Bernardete

texts.pt:
Bernadete is a single mom. She lives with her son in her parents’ house. Bernadete’s parents are country people. They live from working on their small farm. Bernadete entered the loan program this year to save money and get her life in order. She wants to build a home for herself and her son and ensure his schooling. If the business does well, she plans to later sell clothing as well.

Translated from Portuguese by Leo Duran, Kiva Volunteer.

Bernardete e mae solteira. Ela vive com o seu filho na casa de seus pais. Os pais de Bernardete sao camponeses. Vivem do trabalha da pequena machamba. Bernardete entrou para o programa de credito neste ano para poder juntar dinheiro para organizar sua vida. A saber construir sua propria residencia onde quer viver com o seu filho, assegurar os estudos do filho. Se o negocio correr bem ela pensa mais tarde passar a vender tambem roupa.

loans.use: Bernadete would like to use the money to buy more products for her store

loans.name: Raquelina Francisco

texts.pt:
Raquelina is single but lives with a man with whom she has 2 children. Raquelina’s partner is unemployed but gets by doing small jobs and working on the family's farm. Raquelina also works on the farm with her partner. However, she would like to improve her family's life and, in particular, guarantee schooling for her children. For this reason she decided to enter the loan program this year. If the business does well, she plans to make improvements on her house together with her husband. In order to cover the household expenses, Raquelina sometimes sells vegetables that she gets from her farm.

Translated from Portuguese by Leo Duran, Kiva Volunteer.

Raquelina e solteira mas vive com um homem de quem tem 2 filhos. o marido de raquelina nao esta empregado ele vive de pequenos expedientes e trabalha na machamba da familia. raquelina tambem trabalha na machamba juntamente com seu marido. mas porque quer melhorar a vida de sua familia principalmente garantir a escola para os seus filhos, ela resolveu entrar para o programa de credito ainda este ano. Se o negocio correr bem ela pensa juntamente com o marido melhorar a casa onde vivem. para alem de pagar as despesas da casa. raquelina as vezes tambem vende legumes que tira de sua machamba.

loans.use: Raquelina would like to use the money to buy more wrap skirts for the business

loans.name: Amancia Elias

texts.pt:
Amancia is a married mother of 1. She lives with her son in her own house built from local materials. She lives in Chissano and sells clothing in the town's market. Since Chissano is in a rural area, Amancia also works on a small farm. Amancia’s son attends primary school. Amancia would like to use the money to buy more clothing for the business. She just entered the program this year. This is the first loan she will take.

Translated from Portuguese by Leo Duran, Kiva Volunteer.

Amancia e mae solteira e tem 1 filho. Ela vive com o seu filho em sua propria casa construida de material local. Ela vive em Chissano e vende no mercado de Chissano.Porque Chissano e uma zona rural, Amancia tambem trabalha em sua pequena machamba.Por isso as vezes ela tambem vende legumes que tira de sua machamba. O filho de Amancia estuda no nivel primario basico. Ela quer usar o dinheiro para a compra de mais roupa para a venda.Ela entrou para o programa ainda este ano. Este e o primeiro emprestimo que ela vai tomar.

loans.use: Amancia would like to use the money to buy more clothing for the business

loans.name: Julius

texts.en: Julius is a 29-year-old businesswoman and a resident of the Lumo area, a Dar Es Salaam city suburb. Julius has been in business for the past three years, and currently she is running a shop selling mobile phones and their accessories, a business which is becoming so famous and competitive. She is in need of USD 325 to help her expand stock and thus boost her business.

loans.use: Expand Business

loans.name: Ashura

texts.en: Ashura is a 40-year-old mother of four and a resident of Lumo in Dar Es Salaam city. She sells fish in the area. She wakes up early and goes to the landing site for the fishermen at the ocean. She sells some fried and others she sells freshly. She is in need of USD 325 help her boost her capital and expand the business.

loans.use: EXPAND BUSINESS

loans.name: Francisca Maria Luci

texts.pt:
Francisca is a married mother of 7. Francisca’s husband is a self-employed carpenter. He has a small carpentry shop. She entered the loan program in 2006. She would like to use the money to invest in the business. She entered the program to help her husband support the children. All of the children attend school. The husband’s earnings from the shop are meager, forcing her to somehow help cover the household expenses. She is now in her fourth cycle. She would like to expand her business by selling school bags. If all goes well, she plans to help her husband renovate their home.

Translated from Portuguese by Leo Duran, Kiva Volunteer.

Francisca e casad e mae de 7 filhos. O marido de Francisco e carpinteiro por conta propria. Tem uma pequena oficina de carpintaria. Ela entrou para o programa de credito em 2006.Ela quer usar o dinheiro para investir no negocio. Ela entrou parao programa para poder ajudar o marido a sustentar os filhos. Todos os filhos estao a estudar o marido nao tem grandes rendimentos na oficina por isso ela tinha que fazer alguma coisa para ajudar nas despesas da casa.Ela esta agora no quarto ciclo. Ela quer introduzir no seu negocio a venda de pastas escolares como forma de ampliar o seu negocio. Se tudo correr bem ela pensa ajudar o marido na reabilitacao da casa onde vivem.

loans.use: Francisca would like to use the money to buy more bundles of used clothing for the business

loans.name: Mahir

texts.en:
Mahir K. lives in Ashigli village of Beylagan, a small city in southwestern Azerbaijan. He is 55 years old, is married and has five children.

Mahir is engaged in cattle-breeding. He has 15 years experience at this business. He needs $900 to buy one cow.

loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Husan

texts.en:
Husan A. lives in Beylagan, a small city in southwestern Azerbaijan. He is 48 years old, married and has two children.

Husan is a taxi driver. He wants to repair his car. He applied to Normicro Beylagan Branch for a loan in the amount of $500.

loans.use: To repair his car

loans.name: Mubariz

texts.en:
Mubariz G. lives in Ashigli village of Beylagan, a small city in southwestern Azerbaijan. He is 35 years old and is single.

Mubariz is engaged in cattle-breeding. He wants to increase the number of his cows. To do that, he needs an $800 loan.

loans.use: To expand his business

loans.name: Neema

texts.en: Neema is a 30-year-old, hard-working woman and runs a shop selling both used and new clothes in the Vituka area in Dar Es Salaam city. She has been doing this business for the past 7 years. She is in need of USD 225 to help her boost her capital and expand her business.

loans.use: expand business

loans.name: Aydin

texts.en:
Aydin K. lives in Beylagan, a small city in southwestern Azerbaijan. He is 43 years old, married and has one son.

He owns a woodcraft business store near his home. Aydin started his business seven years ago. He borrowed three loans from Normicro Beylagan Branch and expanded his business. Now he needs $900 to buy new materials for his store.

loans.use: To expand his business

loans.name: Jamila

texts.en:
Jamila Z. lives in Beylagan, a small city in southwestern Azerbaijan. She is 47 years old and has one son. Her husband died 10 years ago.

She and her son sell clothes, perfumes, etc. in the city bazaar. She started her business after her husband died. She needs $1,200 to buy more kinds of goods and expand her business.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Nuru

texts.en: Nuru is a 38-year-old mother of three and a resident of the Lumo area in Dar Es Salaam city. She has been in business for the past six years and currently runs a shop selling food items. She mainly deals in maize, flour, wheat, rice, beans and other cereal products that make up common meals for Dar Es Salaam city residents. She is in need of USD 225 to help her expand her business.

loans.use: EXPAND BUSINESS

loans.name: Calixta

texts.es:
Calixta lives down in Domingo Abreu Gomez street, Complemento Yunguyo neighborhood, El Alto city. She lives alone with her 3 years old boy because her husband works as a motor mechanic out of town. She'll use the loan to purchase merchandise for her general store, located in the Alto Lima area where she sells mass consumption goods. It's her first credit with Impro and she qualifys for the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Augusto Salazar, Kiva volunteer.

Calixta vive en la calle Domingo Abreu Gomez de la zona Complemento Yunguyo de la ciudad de El Alto . Vive junto a su hijo de tres años, pues su esposo trabaja como mecánico fuera de la cuidad. El crédito lo destinara para la compra de mercadería, pues posee una tienda de abarrotes en la zona de Alto Lima, donde vende artículos de consumo masivo. Es el primer crédito con Impro y la evaluación realizada le califica para otorgarle el préstamo.

loans.use: to purchase goods

loans.name: Roberto

texts.es:
Roberto lives in San Bartolomé street, Villa Cooperativa neighborhood, El Alto city. He lives with his wife and 3 children aged 16,12 and 9 years old respectively. He'll use the loan money to purchase merchandise for the workshop he owns wiht his cousin. They fold metal plates which are used to build doors afterwards. It's his third credit with Impro and his good payment record qualifys him for the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Augusto Salazar, Kiva volunteer.

Roberto vive en la calle San Bartolomé de la zona Villa cooperativa de la ciudad de El Alto. Vive junto a su esposa y 3 hijos de 16,12 y 9 años respectivamente. El crédito lo destinara para la compra de mercadería, pues se dedica al plegado de planchas metálicas las cuales los comercializa para la construcción de puertas metálicas en un taller que comparte con su primo. Es el tercer crédito con Impro, la evaluación realizada le califica para otorgarle el préstamo, además de tener un buen record de pagos con nuestra Institución.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Zainabu

texts.en: Zainabu, 55, is a mother of three and a resident of Buguruni in Dar Es Salaam City. She sells used and new clothes at her shop located in the Buguruni area, a business she has been doing for the past ten years. She sometimes travels by train up country to sell her clothes. She is in need of USD 550 to help her boost her business.

loans.use: EXPAND BUSINESS

loans.name: Lourdes

texts.es:
Doña Lourdes lives in 192, street "c" in the area of Rio Seco in the town of El Alto.

She is divorced and lives with her two sons, 16 and 1 year of age.

The loan will be used to buy raw material for the preparation of dow and special kinds of bread which is being sold in the area where she lives.

It is the first loan granted to Doña Lourdes by Impro, and the socio-economic evaluation qualifies her to receive the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck, Kiva volunteer.

Lourdes vive en el plan 192 calle “c” de la zona de Rio Seco de la ciudad de El Alto.

La señora es divorciada y vive junto a sus dos hijos de 16 y 1 años respectivamente.

El crédito lo destinara para la compra de mercadería, pues ella se dedica a la elaboración de masas y panes especiales, los cuales los comercializa en la zona en la que vive.

Es el primer crédito con Impro, la evaluación socioeconómica realizada le califica para otorgarle el préstamo.

loans.use: Purchase raw material for the preparation of dow for a specialized bakery.

loans.name: Sabina

texts.es:
Doña Sabina is a farmer and she also breeds cattle. The production of milk from her cattle is commercialized at "PIL Andina", "Planta Industrializadora de Leche", an industrialized milk factory.

She lives in the Community of Chuñochuñini, Laja sector, located three and a half hours from the town of La Paz. She lives with her husband and 4 children, 20, 18, 16, and 14 years of age who all help her out in her daily activities.

The loan will be used to purchase a cow to increase the production of milk.

It is her first loan through Impro and the evaluation qualifies her positively for the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck, Kiva volunteer.

Sabina es agricultora y también cría ganado vacuno, cuya producción la comercializa a PIL Andina (Planta Industrializadora de Leche).

Vive en la Comunidad de Chuñochuñini sector Laja a tres horas y media de la ciudad de La Paz. Ella vive junto a su esposo y 4 hijos de 20, 18, 16,14 años respectivamente quienes le colaboran en sus diarias actividades.

El crédito lo destinara para la compra de una vaca lechera para incrementar la producción de leche.

Es el primer crédito con Impro; la evaluación realizada la califica para otorgarle el préstamo.

loans.use: Purchase a cow to increase production of milk.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for IMPRO - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Kwaku

texts.en:
Kwaku was proud to see the birth of his first child just last week. He is working hard to support his new family and hopes to receive a loan to expand his business. Kwaku sells clothing and polyester. He wishes to expand his stock by purchasing 65 new bundles of polyester. Polyester is commonly used as lining for Ghanaian dresses. With the profit he makes, he is hoping to expand his stall at the local Kumasi market.

His business has already seen a lot of growth in the past couple of years. He has made many connections with distributors and customers around town. He hopes in the future to use these connections to build a successful business in order to spend more time with his family.

loans.use: Purchase 65 bundles of polyester

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en: Mariam B. is a 30-year-old dynamic woman. She lives with her cohabitant and their 3 children in Adjamé, a populated suburb in the north of the Abidjan district. She is a fruits and legumes seller in the Adjamé market, where she has been operating for more than 10 years. Her cohabitant is a taxi driver, and the family has been able to send 2 of their kids to school. Mariam, who benefited from her first loan from AE&I in July 2004, has been an excellent performer and has consistently taken advantage of these loans to improve her business. The volume of her goods has progressively increased. She will use the loan to purchase onions and tomatoes in bulk for gross sale.

loans.use: Mariam Bamba will use the loan to purchase goods in bulk.

loans.name: Sobeida

texts.es:
"I'm making progress with the construction work but I'd like to install the concrete roof, the windows and an extra door to protect my house for the rainy season". I ask for $ 1,200.00 dollars in order to install the roof, the windows and a door.

Translated from Spanish by Augusto Salazar, Kiva volunteer.

“Ya tengo adelantada mi construcción pero me gustaría poner ahora el techo de concreto, las ventanas y un puerta más que nada para proteger mi casa de la temporada de lluvias y de frío”. Solicito $ 1,200.00 dlls para la poner el techo de concreto, las ventanas y una puerta en mi casa.

loans.use: installing a concrete roof, windows and a door.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Fundación para la Vivienda Progresiva (FVP), a partner of CHF International - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Tina

texts.en: Tina is a 25 year old mother from the village of Safaatoa Tai. She has 2 kids who are not in school.  She runs a business selling popcorn and ice cream cake to make money for herself and her family.  She delivers to the village people and the primary school in her village. She has a hard working husband who runs a plantation business to support their family.  She earned $150 a week from the popcorn and ice cream cake and $200 from their taro banana and yam plantation.  She would like to borrow $850 from SPBD which is her 6th loan to expand her business and renovate her home.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her popcorn and ice-cake business

loans.name: Bismarck Antonio

texts.es:
Mr Bismarck Antonio M. was born and lives in the town of Bluefields, he is 41 years old, his life partner is Mrs. Arien Siu, and they have 3 children living with them. Mr. M. has more than 20 years experience as a barber, he has an assistant who also makes haircuts, shaves beards and trims moustaches. His customers are children, men and women of all ages. At the barber shop customers can watch tv programs as well as buy soft drinks or water and therefore it is very popular.

Mr. M. needs to invest in 4 haircutting machines, $48.00 each, (2 machines for cutting and 2 for trimming), 4 boxes of razor blades, $10.00 each, 5 bottles of cologne, $3.00 each, 3 bottles of shaving foam, $2.00 each, 3 boxes of soft drinks, $5.00 each box, 2 boxes of water, $6.00 each box, and 2 gallons of paint, $10.00 per gallon. The paint will be used to improve the image of the barber shop.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck, Kiva volunteer.

El Sr. Bismarck Antonio M. es originario de la ciudad de Bluefields, tiene 41 años de edad, su pareja de vida es la Sra. Arlen Siu, ambos tiene 3 hijos que viven con la pareja. El Sr. M. tiene mas de 20 años de experiencia , tiene un empleado que tambien corta pelo, afeite de barba y recorte de bigote sus clientes son niños, hombres y mujeres de todas las edades, esta barberia los entretiene con programas de television , tambien pueden comprar gaseosas o agua por esta razon son preferidos.

El Sr. M. necesita invertir en 4 maquinas de cortar pelo a $ 48.00 dolares cada maquina (2 maquinas para cortar pelo y las otras 2 para el acabado), 4 cajas de guillet a $10.00 dolares cada caja, 5 colonias de barberia a $3.00 cada colonia, 3 botellas de espuma para afeitar a $2.00 dolares, 3 cajas de gaseosas a $ 5.00 dolares cada caja, 2 cajas de agua a $6.00 dolares cada caja, 2 galones de pintura a $ 10.00 dolares cada galon. La pintura la necesita para mejorar la imagen de la barberia.

loans.use: Purchase haircutting machines, razor blades, cologne, shaving foam, soft drinks, water and paint to improve image and offer better service.

loans.name: Juan Francisco

texts.es:
Juan is a 54 year-old married man and lives with his wife. Owing to forces beyond their control, his wife is constantly traveling. Juan also lives with one of his daughters, who is independent and married. Juan dedicates himself to the repair of all types of vehicles. He has years of experience in his line of work. He doesn't have much competition, owing to the well known high quality of his work and the large demand of his clients. The price of each repair varies according to the type of job he does. Juan has had three credit loans in the past with this institution. All have been paid off without problems. This is his fourth loan request.

Translated from Spanish by Geoff Rubin, Kiva volunteer.

JUAN ES UN SEÑOR CASADO DE 54 AÑOS DE EDAD. VIVE CON SU ESPOSA QUIEN ESTA CONSTANTEMENTE DE VIAJE POR MOTIVOS DE FUERZA MAYOR, TAMBIEN VIVE CON UNA DE SUS HIJAS QUIEN ES INDEPENDIENTE Y CASADA. JUAN SE DEDICA A LA CHAPERIA DE TODO TIPO DE VEHÍCULOS, TIENE VARIOS AÑOS DE EXPERIENCIA EN EL RUBRO. NO TIENE MUCHA COMPETENCIA PORQUE DEBIDO A LA CALIDAD DE TRABAJO QUE REALIZA ES MUY CONOCIDO Y TIENE BASTANTE DEMANDA DE CLIENTELA. EL PRECIO DE CADA CHAPERIA DE AUTO VARIA DE ACUERDO AL TRABAJO QUE SE REALIZA. TUVO ANTERIORMENTE TRES CREDITOS CON NUESTRA INSTITUCION QUE HAN SIDO CANCELADOS SIN PROBLEMAS, AHORA ES SU CUARTO CREDITO.

loans.use: The construction of a platform in his home

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Fundación Agrocapital, a partner of ACDI/VOCA - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Eulogio

texts.es:
Eulogio is a 49 year-old married man. He lives in his own house in the neighborhood of San Antonio de Warnes, the southwest zone. He cares for his two children and his wife sells refreshments in the central market of the capital on Thursdays and Sundays. Eulogio is a shoe maker. He runs his small shoe workshop on the sidewalk of a central street in Warnes. He has been doing this for at least three years and has a lot of experience. He therefore has a fair amount of clients. The competition is minimal, as Eulogio is the only shoemaker in the area and there are no other shoemakers within 500 meters. Eulogio wants to buy construction materials so that he can finish his floor and bathroom. This is the sixth loan he has requested from this institution, all of which he has reimbursed punctually. He does not have credit with another institution.

Translated from Spanish by Geoff Rubin, Kiva volunteer.

EULOGIO ES UN SEÑOR CASADO DE 49 AÑOS DE EDAD, VIVE EN SU PROPIA CASA DEL BARRIO SAN ANTONIO DE WARNES, ZONA SUR OESTE. TIENE DOS HIJOS A SU CARGO, SU ESPOSA VENDE REFRESCOS EN EL MERCADO CENTRAL DE ESTA CAPITAL, LOS DIAS JUEVES Y DOMINGOS. EULOGIO ES ZAPATERO, TIENE SU PEQUEÑO TALLER DE ZAPATERIA EN LA VEREDA DE UNA CALLE CENTRICA DE WARNES, ACTIVIDAD QUE LLEVA POR LO MENOS UNOS TRES AÑOS, POR LO CUAL TIENE MUCHA EXPERIENCIA Y POR ENDE BASTANTES CLIENTES. LA COMPETENCIA ES BAJA, YA QUE ES EL UNICO ZAPATERO EN LA ZONA, NO EXISTE OTRO A MENOS DE 500 MTS. EL CLIENTE COMPRARA MATERIALES DE CONSTRUCCION PARA TERMINAR UNA PIEZA Y SU BAÑO EQUIVALENTE AL MONTO SOLICITADO. ESTE ES SU SEXTO PRESTAMO EN NUESTRA INSTITUCION LOS CUALES A PAGADO PUNTUALMENTE. NO TIENE NINGUN OTRO CREDITO EN OTRA INSTITUCION.

loans.use: To finish his house

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Fundación Agrocapital, a partner of ACDI/VOCA - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Maliana

texts.en: Maliana L.’s barbeque business generates most of her family income. She supports her husband who is unemployed, and her three children. Although it is difficult for Ms. L., who is 31 years old, she is determined to keep up her good work and earn more than 500 tala ($200 US) to cover her loan. She sells her barbequed food five days a the week by the road side in front of her house.

loans.use: To buy ingredients and supplies for her barbecue business

loans.name: Rita

texts.es:
Rita is a 42 year old married woman. She sells chickens in the central market of Warnes. Currently she lives in her own home in the town of San Antonio, southwest of Warnes. Her husband has a small chicken farm in their home, and he gets Rita the chickens plus he sells them to outsiders when they are in season. They have three children. Rita sells chickens in the Central market of Warnes, she has been in this business for several years, and the business is in a good corner location, so she always has customers. Competition is average since there are other sellers but there is only one more in her area, so she has many clients and she sells plenty. She will buy 1500 BB chickens at a price of $0.36 each. This is her fifth credit with our institution (all the other ones she has already paid). She has two other credits with two institutions: one with Crecer and one with Prodem which she is paying on time.

Translated from Spanish by Samantha, Kiva Volunteer.

RITA ES UNA SEÑORA CASADA DE 42 AÑOS DE EDAD. ELLA VENDE CARNE DE POLLO (POLLOS) AL POR MENOR, ZONA DEL MERCADO CENTRAL DE WARNES. ACTUALMENTE VIVE EN SU PROPIA CASA DEL BARRIO SAN ANTONIO, ZONA SUR OESTE DE WARNES, SU ESPOSO TIENE SU PEQUEÑA GRANJA AVICOLA (RUDIMENTARIA) EN SU DOMICILIO, DE DONDE LE PROVEE POLLOS A RITA Y TAMBIÉN VENDE A OTROS CUANDO ES LA EPOCA. LA PAREJA TIENE TRES HIJOS A SU CARGO. EL PUESTO DE VENTAS DE RITA ES EN LA ZONA DEL MERCADO CENTRAL DE WARNES, EXTERNO. LLEVA BASTANTES AÑOS EN EL NEGOCIO Y EN UNA MUY BUENA UBICACIÓN, PLENA ESQUINA POR LO QUE CLIENTES NO LE FALTAN. LA COMPETENCIA ES MEDIANA POR LO QUE HAY OTRAS VENDEDORAS, PERO EN SU LUGAR SOLO HAY UNA MAS, POR TAL MOTIVO TIENE MUCHA CLIENTELA Y POR ENDE MUCHA SALIDA DEL PRODUCTO. LA CLIENTE COMPRARA 1,500 UNIDADES DE POLLITOS BEBE A UN PRECIO DE $US. 0,36 CADA UNO. ESTE ES SU QUINTO PRESTAMO EN NUESTRA INSTITUCION, LOS CUALES A PAGADO EXCELENTEMENTE. TIENE DOS CREDITOS EN OTRAS INSTITUCIONES; UNO EN CRECER Y EL OTRO EN PRODEM QUE ESTA CANCELANDO PUNTUALMENTE.

loans.use: To buy BB chickens

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Fundación Agrocapital, a partner of ACDI/VOCA - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Tinei

texts.en: Tinei is 48 years old and is married with seven kids. Two of her kids are in school and others are married. She is a hard-working mother who runs her own BBQ business. She started the BBQ business and because of her success, she is only now asking for her second loan. She has a strong work ethic with what she is doing. Tinei earns $180 profit a day from selling her BBQ. It is fun when she sells the BBQ everyday on the road in front of her house. With the next loan, she is planning to renovate her house.

loans.use: To buy ingredients and supplies for her barbecue business

loans.name: Rogerio Martin

texts.es:
The micro-entrepreneur Rogerio Martín C. is 45 years old, lives in the city of Bluefields, is married and has three kids. Two study in primary school and one at the secondary level. For the past six years he has dedicated himself to the jewelry profession, making rings, earrings, gold chains, as well as repairing these same products. Currently he has a large quantity of requests for graduation rings but due to lack of money he cannot buy the stones and gold needed to make them. This demand for rings is because in the months of November and December many High School graduations occur and as a remembrance students buy rings with engravings alluding to their respective schools. In order to facilitate the purchase of his products, Mr. C. allows customers to pay for the rings in four or five installments, since for many parents it is difficult to pay the total cost of these rings all at one time. Micro-entrepreneur C. employs one other person who he pays a head of the household (full-time) salary. The cost of the square stones used for rings is $2.00 U.S. each, the stones for graduation rings are valued at $3.00 US, a pound of plaster costs $2.00 US, and a gram of gold can be purchased for $8.00.

Translated from Spanish by Debra Faszer-McMahon, Kiva Volunteer.

El microempresario Rogerio Martín C. tiene 45 años de edad, habita en la ciudad de Bluefields, es casado y tiene 3 hijos, dos estudian en primaria y uno en nivel secundario. Desde hace 6 años se dedica a la profesión de joyero fabricando anillos, aretes, cadenas de oro, así como la reparación de estos mismos productos. Actualmente tiene una gran cantidad de pedidos de anillos de promoción pero por falta de dinero no puede comprar las piedras y el oro para su elaboración. Esta demanda de anillos se debe a que en los meses de noviembre y diciembre se realizan las graduaciones del nivel secundario y como recuerdo los estudiantes compran anillos con grabaciones alusivas a sus respectivos colegios. El señor C. a fin de dar facilidades en las compras de sus productos les permite pagar los anillos en cuatro o cinco partes valorando que a muchos padres de familia se les dificulta pagar de una sola vez el total de estos anillos. El microempresario C. tiene contratado a una persona por lo que aporta a la generación de empleo de una cabeza de familia. El valor de las piedras cuadradas para anillos es de US$ 2.00 dólares cada una, las piedras para anillos de promoción están valoradas en US$ 3.00 dólares cada una, la libra de yeso cuesta US$ 2.00 dólares cada libra y el gramo de oro se compra a US$ 8.00 cada gramo.

loans.use: To buy 20 square stones for various rings, 20 stones for graduation rings, 10 pounds of plaster, and 20 grams of gold.

payments.comment: La cuota real es de $56.16 dólares

loans.name: Moana

texts.en: Moana is one of the older ladies within the Apolima borrowing center. She weaves fine mats, which are used for special events such as weddings and funerals. Weaving fine mats takes an incredible amount of time and patience, but just twenty inches of fine mats sells for about 2000 Tala or $800. It is very profitable and that’s why Moana prefers does this to make money. This is her 6th loan and she needs $300 to help her business turn a profit.

loans.use: To buy traditional Samoan materials, including laufala and fulumoa for creating fine mats (ietoga)

loans.name: Lina

texts.en: Lina A.’s business is making ice cakes out of cordial and sugar. She sells them for five cents per ice cake and she can sell about fifty ice cakes a day. She sells five days of the week and she can earn about 50-60 Tala ($20-24 US) a day. Lina is one of the oldest and most supportive members of her borrowing center and she is looking to start another business in the future to supplement her income.

loans.use: To buy ingredients and supplies for her ice cake business

loans.name: Elena

texts.en: Elena is the secretary of Samatau 3 Center. She is one of the most active members of the loan program. She sells traditional Samoan clothing: puletasi for women, and aloa for men. She also does elei, a printing method on a traditional Samoan material that makes clothing. She is one of the oldest members of SPBD, and this will be her 6th loan. She is still running her business successfully and will be looking for more loans in the future.

loans.use: To buy fabrics and other supplies for her sewing business

loans.name: Tiperia

texts.en: Tiperia is married, and 25 years old. She has run a vegetable garden business for the past few years. She grows cabbages, cucumbers, beans, and tomatoes, and in addition grows taro, taamu and bananas. Tiperia sells these foods at the Fugalei Market, and earns about 60 USD a day. This would be her first loan, and Tiperia is eager to join the business cycle and she is excited to become more active within her borrowing center.

loans.use: To buy chemicals and equipment for her vegetable garden

loans.name: Telesia

texts.en: Telesia S. is a 50 year old mother of three children.  One of her daughters is a lawyer. Telesia is looking after her grandson and uses most of her time at home to grow and plant flowers beside her house. She is one of the oldest members of the Aleisa borrowing center and this is her sixth loan. When it’s too hot in the daytime, Telesia will do her elei printing. She sells her plants and flowers from home, and she also delivers her lavalava (a Samoan sarong) to the village shops.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her elei (a traditional Samoan printing material) printing, florist business, and vegetable garden

loans.name: Elisapeta

texts.en: Elisapeta is married to a farmer from Tiavea. She is 21 years old and has one child. Her business is taro plantation, and she sells her crops in front of her house. She also sells at the market twice a week. She makes about 250-300 Tala ($100-$120 US) which she also she uses to support her family and to pay for her kid school fees.

loans.use: To buy supplies and equipment for her plantation

loans.name: Faaafe

texts.en: Faaafe is 49 years of age and has 4 children. She is started the borrowing centre in February in the village of Samusu. Her first loan of 750.00 Tala ($300.00 US) was used to buy chemicals for her three acre taro plantation quite far from her house. She used to go to the market twice a week where she earned 200.00-300.00 Tala ($80-120 US). She is applying for another 1250.00 Tala ($500.00 US) loan to extend her taro plantation and to help out with her family remittances.

loans.use: To buy supplies and equipment for her plantation

loans.name: Puao

texts.en: Puao is married and has three children.  She owns a taro plantation.  Her sons and her husband help her maintain the plantation.  Her last loan of 1250 Tala, or $500, was also used to buy supplies for her business. She applied for this loan so that she can support her family while continuing to expand her plantation.

loans.use: To buy supplies and equipment for her plantation

loans.name: Venise

texts.en: Venise's work consists of running a 6-acre taro plantation which is tended by her husband and four laborers.  Most of her family moved overseas but she chose to remain in Samoa and continue her taro plantation. She goes to the market twice a month and makes 300-400 Tala ($120-160 US) each visit.

loans.use: To buy supplies, such as fertilizers, spades, and knives, for her plantation

loans.name: Sipau

texts.en: Sipau is 47 years old, married, and the mother of four children. She has never stopped looking for a business to support herself and her family. Currently, she grows vegetables in her garden with her husband. She brings her produce to the flea market in front of her house, and also brings her vegetables to the newly opened market at Fugalei. She typically earns $200 to $300 a week, and the money is spent to support her children’s education and her family’s expenses.

loans.use: To buy supplies and equipment for her vegetable garden

loans.name: Alisi

texts.en: Alisi is new at the Levili Toefuataina borrowing centre. She is 22 years old and a mother of one child. Her business is operating a small shop in front of her house which is open every day from 7.00am – 6.00pm. She is planning to buy more inventory for her shop with her loan.

loans.use: To restock her shop

loans.name: Dayu Inten

texts.id:
Dayu Inten W. has been selling in her kiosk for a while. Each day she goes to the market at 5 am to purchase goods to be sold, with the help of her husband. After obtaining the goods, she opens her kiosk at 7 am. She arranged her merchandise nicely to attract customers. She sells variety of snacks from noodle soup, side dishes, and Balinese traditional salad, Gado-gado. With funding and training help from DINARI, Dayu Inten W. is trying to expand her kiosk. She has many regular cutomers in her village. With $2.20 Profit each day, Dayu Inten can supplement her husband's income to support her family

Translated from Indonesian by Kresna Hartandi, KIva Volunteer

Usaha warung yang ditekuni Dayu Inten W. sudah lama dijalani. Setiap pagi mulai pukul 05.00 pagi sudah pergi ke pasar utuk mencari darang dagangan dengan diantar oleh suaminya. Setelah memperoleh barang dagangan baru membuka warungnya mulai pukul 07.00 pagi . Barang - barang dagangan mulai dipajang dan dirapikan agar terlihat menarik. Barang-barang yang dijual yaitu aneka macam makanan ringan dan mie rebus, lauk-pauk siap saji dan makanan khas Bali, yaitu Gado – gado. Dengan bantuan dana dan pembinaan dari Yayasan DINARI Dayu Inten W. memakai untuk melengkapi usaha warungnya.Usaha warung ini ditekuni karena sudah mempunyai banyak pelanggan didesanya. Dengan keuntungan bersih Rp. 20.000,- setiap harinya Dayu Inten dapat membantu pendapatan suaminya dan menopang perekonomian keluarganya.

loans.use: Increase capital to increase merchandise offering

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for DINARI Foundation - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Fialauia

texts.en: H. Fialauia is 33 years of age and is the mother of 3 school children. She and her husband tend to their taro plantation six days a week. She sells 3-4 bags of taro at the market twice a week for which she recieves 300-400 Tala ($120-160 US) a month. She uses this money to send her children to school, and she will use the loan to expand on her four-acre taro plantation.

loans.use: To buy supplies and equipment for her plantation

loans.name: Ni Ketut Suarmi

texts.id:
Ni Ketut Suarmi is used to working hard. She raises and fatten pig in her yards to support her family's income. From her farm income, she managed to afford high school tuition for her 3 children that now can support themselves independently. She pays so much attention on her 2 pigs that she is growing, so that the 2 piglets she purchsed for $50 can now be sold for $100, the net profit of about $35 can be used to afford the ever increasing living expenses. Ni Ketut is also thinking of her old age, when she will not be as productive as she is now. Ni Ketut plans to improve her farming techniques and expand her farm by adding more pigs. She also needs more money to pay for feeds that are becoming more expensive. She hopes to achieve all these using the loan from DINARI, which may help her optimally expand her business.

Translated from Indonesian by Kresna Hartandi, Kiva Volunter

Ni Ketut Suarmi terbiasa dengan kehidupan yang selalu diisi dengan kerja keras. Walaupun sebagai wanita biasa, tetapi Ni Ketut Suarmi tidak mau tinggal diam saja melihat suami bekerja keras untuk menghidupi keluarga. Ni Ketut Suarmi ikut ambil bagian dalam mengusahakan kesejahteraan keluarganya dengan memelihara babi penggemukan di sekitar pekarangan rumahnya. Karena keuletannya, Ni Ketut Suarmi mampu menyekolahkan 3 orang anaknya sampai mereka tamat pendidikan menengah dan akhirnya bisa bekerja untuk mencukupi kebutuhan hidupnya masing-masing. 2 ekor babi penggemukan yang dipeliharanya diperhatikannya dengan sangat baik sehingga dari dua ekor bibit yang dibelinya dengan harga Rp 450.000 dalam waktu 2,5 bulan mampu dijual dengan seharga Rp 900.000 dan keuntungan bersih yang diperolehnya sekitar Rp 300.000 dan itu dipakai untuk menutupi biaya hidup yang semakin tinggi. Ni Ketut Suarmi juga memikirkan hari tuanya yang tentu saja tidak bisa seproduktif seperti sekarang, sehingga Ni Ketut Suarmi pun berusaha keras untuk mengelola usahanya dengan baik yaitu dengan berencana menambah jumlah ternak yang dipelihara serta menyediakan stok pakan yang memadai karena harga pakan sudah semakin mahal. Dengan menjalin kerjasama dengan DINARI lewat pinjaman modal usaha, Ni Ketut Suarmi melihat peluang untuk mengembangkan usahanya untuk mendapat hasil yang maksimal.

loans.use: Purchase feed and piglets

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for DINARI Foundation - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Jero Darsini

texts.id:
Jero Darsini is used to hard work helping her husband, Gusti Ketut Ratuh supporting their family's income. All of her three children realized how hard the parents work so two of them try to be independent and earn their own livings. Her youngest child is still in primary school, so she still need to pay for his tuition. She saw the opportunity to expand her pig farm. She started with only one pig, and now she owns 3 growing pigs. Each pigs were bought for $25 and farmed for 2 months before sold to a butchery or restaurant for $45. So she earns about $60 from 3 pigs. Jero Darsini plays a big part in earning the family income as her husband's contract farming income is not sufficient. She hopes to expand her farm and increase her profit. She hopes to use the loan from DINARI to achieve that. Jero Darsini is trying to renovate her simple home using the additional profit from the business.

Translated from Indonesian by Kresna Hartandi, Kiva Volunteer

Jero Darsini dalam kehidupan sehari- harinya terbiasa untuk bekerja keras dalam membantu suaminya, Gusti Ketut Rauh, dalam memenuhi segala kebutuhan hidup keluarganya. Tiga orang anaknya sudah merasakan bagaimana uletnya orang tua mereka ini hingga dua diantaranya sudah mampu mandiri dan bekerja, sedangkan anaknya yang masih di sekolah dasar masih harus di biayai pendidikannya. Dari keuletannya dalam menjalankan usaha ternak babi, Jero Darsini melihat ada peluang untuk bisa mengembangkan usahanya. Dimulai dari hanya memelihara seekor babi sampai akhirnya Jero Darsini memelihara 3 ekor babi penggemukan. Babi tersebut dibeli dengan harga Rp 225.000,- per ekor yang dipelihara selama 2 bulan dan di jual kepada pengusaha babi guling dengan harga Rp.400.000, jadi Jero Darsini mendapat pendapatan kotor Rp 525.000 dari ke 3 ekor ternaknya. Dari hasil usahanya inilah Jero Darsini menunjukkan perannya menjadi penopang keuangan keluarga karena penghasilan suaminya sebagai petani tidak cukup untuk memenuhi semua kebutuhan keluarga. Dalam perkembangan usahanya Jero Darsini selalu berharap bisa lebih maju lagi karena kebutuhan hidup semakin meningkat dan lewat pinjaman modal yang diperolehnya dari DINARI besar harapannya bisa mengembangkan usahanya karena Jero Darsini juga sedang berupaya memperbaiki keadaan rumahnya yang sangat sederhana .

loans.use: Purchase growing pigs and feeds.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for DINARI Foundation - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Moevanu

texts.en: Moevanu is a 32-year-old married mother of 4 children. Her business is a retail shop just in front of her house. She serves people of her village every day. She wakes up early each morning and goes to sleep late at night. Her husband is one of the company’s employee and she needs this loan to get some more money for her family remittances and children’s school fees.

loans.use: To restock her shop

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en: Juliet is a 28-year-old married mother of two children, and lives in the village of Livili. She is new at her borrowing centre, and her business sells ice cakes which earns her 100-150 Tala ($40-60 US) a week. She enjoys running her small business because its simple and a quick way to earn money.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her ice cake business

loans.name: Fiso

texts.en: Fiso is a 40-year-old and a mother of six.  She was originally from a village near the main town of Apia, but she has since settled down in the village of Salesatele after marrying. She owns a taro plantation and has just joined the loan program last week to get financial support for her plantation and for her family.

loans.use: To buy equipment and supplies for her plantation

loans.name: Temukisa Wong

texts.en: Temukisa is a strong, married mother of five children. She was employed at one of the companies in Apia but she resigned because she had no one to look after her children. She is now able to make money by selling chips to her fellow villagers and shops in town. She makes around 250-300 Tala ($100-120 US) which she uses for her children’s school fees, family remittances, and growing her business.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her chips business

loans.name: Ana

texts.en: Ana is a determined lady who started her up her shop to support her family. She is a 42-year-old married mother of 8 children. Her small shop is located right in front of her house.  It earns her 300-400 Tala ($120-160 US) a day, which she uses to support her family and pay for her children’s school fees.

loans.use: To restock her shop

loans.name: Tapunuu

texts.en: Tapunuu has 7 children, four boys and three girls, and is happy to have the chance to gather with other ladies from her village during loan group meetings. Tapunuu’s business is running a banana plantation which is tended six days a week by her husband and three of her sons. They earn 200-300 Tala ($80-120 US) each time they go to sell their crops at the market (twice a month) and she used that money for her children’s school fees and support her family.

loans.use: To buy equipment and supplies for her plantation

loans.name: Pua

texts.en: Pua is one of the new members at the Alaoa T borrowing centre. She is 21 years old and has one child. She joined the loan program last week when she needed help for her small business selling chips to her fellow villagers and delivering them to the shops in town. She can earn 100-200 Tala ($40-80 US) a week which she can use to pay back family remittances from relatives overseas.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her chips business

loans.name: Tasilua

texts.en: Tasilua is 48 years old and the mother of 3 children. She and her family live in the village of Vaimoso. Her husband used to help her with the family’s canteen business, but he passed away during the beginning of this year. She joined SPBD in 2006, and borrowed $300 initially to begin her business. This will be her second loan from SPBD, and she hopes to expand her current business with a mini market. She currently earns $140 after expenses per week from her canteen business, and the additional profit will be used to support her family and to pay back the loans she currently has.

loans.use: To buy supplies and inventory for her canteen

loans.name: Christina

texts.en: Christina, who hails from the village of Vaimoso, is 44-years old and has 7 kids. She runs a fast food stall business, which she runs 3 day a week on Monday, Wednesday and Friday. She sells 50 plates a day at the Vaimoso Primary school, which nets her $52 after all expenses. Her last loan amount was for $725 and now she is reapplying for the same amount in order to expand her fast food stall and to renovate her home.  Her business helps her to support her 2 school-aged children by paying for school bills, and also with other obligations such as church donations and loan repayments.

loans.use: To buy ingredients and supplies for her fast food stall

loans.name: Suiti

texts.en: Suiti is 42 year old mother from Puipaa Center. She has 4 children, 2 of whom are in school and 2 of whom are working. She runs a plantation of fresh vegetable and sells her produce at the Fugalei market. She was able to purchase the seeds of various kinds of vegetables, mainly cabbages, tomatoes and cucumber, which she was trained to pot. She sells at the market 2 day a week, on Wednesdays and Fridays. She can earn $100 after all costs are deducted, which she uses to support her family and pay back her loans.  Her husband helps her with the vegetable business and also works as a carpenter. He is a foreman and can earn $112 a week. Suiti is applying for a $500 loan to expand her vegetable garden and to help her pay for kids’ school fees.

loans.use: To buy equipment and supplies for her vegetable garden

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
LUCY, a 32-year-old widow, supports her two children, ages 16 and 11, in order that they may attend school. Since 2005, Lucy walks from door to door every day selling various clothes, soaps, and toothpaste. At her home, she makes shirts, for which she gets a profit of around $4.50 per shirt. As her customers generally pay her for her products in small installments, it often takes around one week to collect the money for a single tube of toothpaste or bar of soap, costing 91 cents. For clothing, she often is paid at the end of each month, when her customers receive their salaries. Lucy diligently keeps track of all her customers and visits their homes and offices frequently in order to receive her payments.

Previously, Lucy took out a loan of about $91 which she used to buy her merchandise. Having paid this loan back successfully, she now hopes to take out a larger loan to increase her stock.

Lucy belongs to the group Tujikwamue (Swahili for “progressing from one stage to another”), which consists of 25 other members who keep each other accountable and insure one another in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To increase stock

payments.comment: Lucy successfully paid the remaining of her loan before the end of the loan term!

loans.name: Amina

texts.en: Amina (her husband is pictured) is a mother of two children. She is 28 years old, and she lives in Khudat town. Amina and her husband have been in this business for 2 years. Now this young family needs a loan of  $600 to buy fertilizer and pesticides to improve their orchard farming.

loans.use: Amina would like to buy fertilizer and pesticides for her orchard.

loans.name: Bakhtiyar

texts.en: Bakhtiyar is 27 years old and single. This young man lives in Khachmaz town. He is doing tile cladding on the walls of houses. You can see Bakhtiyar in his own garage, where he keeps all his instruments, in the picture. He has two years of experience in this business. Now he needs a loan of $600 to buy necessary materials for tile cladding.

loans.use: To buy necessary materials for tile cladding

loans.name: Samira

texts.en: Samira is a mother of one child. This young woman is a widow. She lives with her child in Khachmaz town. Samira has three years of experience in the tailoring business.  Now this 28-year-old woman needs a loan of $600 to buy the necessary materials for improving her business.

loans.use: To buy necessary materials for tailoring

loans.name: Shahbaz

texts.en: Shahbaz (his brother is pictured) was born in 1986. This single  man lives in the Khachmaz region, in Hadjialibay village.  Shahbaz and his brother have a fruit orchard. They want to improve their business; that is why they request a loan of $1200. The guys plan to buy fruit seedlings, pesticides and fertilizer for improving their yield. These young guys have  been in this business for two years.

loans.use: To buy fruit seedlings, pesticides and fertilizer

loans.name: Sara

texts.en: Sara (her husband is pictured) is a mother of three children. Sara is 39 years old. She lives in Khachmaz town. Sara and her husband buy the hazels from the villages and sell them wholesale. Now they need a loan of $1200 to buy hazels for getting more income.

loans.use: To buy hazels

loans.name: Sleiman

texts.en: Sleiman is a 28 year old man who lives in south Lebanon in the region of Nabatieh. Sleiman has a restaurant in which he offers chicken, fench fries and other meals. Sleiman is a very ambitious and productive young man who is striving to provide for his family; his wife and his two children. This is the 5th time that Sleiman is asking for a loan from Al Majmoua to grow his business. Sleiman needs to generate enough revenue to be able to buy a car for his family. He wants to take his family for a drive and with all the hard work and efforts he is investing in his restaurant this would be a nice reward.

loans.use: To grow his business and buy a car

loans.name: Wofunira Development Association Group

texts.en:
Robinah is the strong, dynamic chairperson for the Wofunira Development Association, a women’s lending group in the Zana Village. Zana is a village divided by a very busy road between Kampala and Entebbe.
